div.head: PROLOGUE To the Provok'd Wife, spoke by Mistress Bracegirdle.
div.l: SInce 'tis the Intent and Business of the Stage,
To Copy out the Follies of the Age;
To hold to every Man a Faithful Glass,
And shew him of what Species he's an Ass.
I hope the next that teaches in the School,
Will shew our Author he's a scribling Fool.
And that the Satyr may be sure to Bite,
Kind Heav'n! Inspire some venom'd Priest to Write,
And grant some Vgly Lady may Indite.
For I wou'd have him lash'd, by Heav'ns! I would,
Till his presumption swam away in Blood.
Three Plays at once proclaims a Face of Brass,
No matter what they are! That's not the Case,
To Write three Plays, ev'n that's to be an Ass.
But what I least forgive, he knows it too,
For to his Cost he lately has known you.
Experience shews, to many a Writers smart
You hold a Court where mercy ne're had part;
So much of the old Serpent's Sting you have,
You Love to Damn, as Heav'n Delights to Save.
In Foreign Parts, let a bold Voluntiere,
For publick Good upon the Stage appear,
He meets ten thousand Smiles to Dissipate his Fear.
All tickle on, th' adventuring young Beginner,
And only scourge th' incorragible Sinner;
They touch indeed his Faults, but with a hand
So gentle, that his Merit still may stand:
Kindly they Buoy the Follies of his Pen,
That he may shun 'em when he Writes again.
But 'tis not so, in this good natur'd Town,
All's one, an Ox, a Poet, or a Crown,
Old England's play was always knocking Down.

div.head: EPILOGUE, By another Hand.
div.stage: Spoken by Lady Brute and Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.l: NO Epilogue!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I Swear I know of none.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Lord! How shall we excuse it to the Town?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why, we must e'en say something of our own.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Our own! Ay, that must needs be precious stuff.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I'll lay my life they'll like it well enough.
Come Faith begin—

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Excuse me, after you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nay, pardon me for that, I know my Cue.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: O for the World, I would not have Precedence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: O Lord!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I Swear—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: O Fye!

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: I'm all Obedience.
First then, know all, before our Doom is fixt,
The Third day is for us—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nay, and the Sixt.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: We speak not from the Poet now, nor is it
His Cause— (I want a Rhime)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That we solicite.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Then sure you cannot have the hearts to be severe
And Damn us—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Damn us! Let 'em if they Dare.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Why, if they should, what punishment Remains?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Eternal Exile from behind our Scenes.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: But if they're kind, that sentence we'll recal,
We can be grateful—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And have wherewithall.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: But at grand Treaties, hope not to be Trusted,
Before Preliminaries are adjusted.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You know the Time, and we appoint this place;
Where, if you please, we'll meet and sign the Peace.

div.head: THE Provok'd Wife.
ACT the First.

sp.p: WHAT cloying meat is Love,— when Matrimony's the Sauce to it. Two years Marriage has debaucht my five Senses. Every thing I see, every thing I hear, every thing I feel, every thing I smell, and every thing I taste— methinks has Wife in't.
No Boy was ever so weary of his Tutor; no Girl of her Bib; no Nun of doing Penance nor Old Maid of being Chast, as I am of being Married.

Sure there's a secret Curse entail'd upon the very Name of Wife. My Lady is a young Lady, a fine Lady, a Witty Lady, a Virtuous Lady— and yet I hate her. There is but one thing on Earth I loath beyond her: That's fighting. Wou'd my Courage come up but to a fourth part of my Ill Nature, I'd stand buff to her Relations, and thrust her out of Doors.
But Marriage has sunk me down to such an Ebb of Resolution, I dare not draw my Sword, tho even to get rid of my Wife. But here she comes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you Dine at home to day, Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Why, do you expect I shou'd tell you, what I don't know my self?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I thought there was no harm in asking you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: If thinking wrong were an excuse for Impertinence, Women might be justifi'd in most things they say or do.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'm sorry I have said any thing to displease you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Sorrow for things past, is of as little Importance to me, as my dining at home or a broad ought to be to you.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: My Enquiry was only that I might have provided what you lik'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Six to four you had been in the wrong there again, for what I lik'd yesterday I don't like to day, and what I like to day, 'tis odds I may'nt like to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: But if I had ask'd you what you lik'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Why then there would have been more asking about it, than the thing was worth.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I wish I did but know how I might please you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Ay, but that sort of knowledge is not a Wife's Talent.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What e'er my Talent is, I'm sure my Will has ever been to make you easie.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: If Women were to have their Wills, the World wou'd be finely govern'd.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What reason have I given you to use me as you do of late? It once was otherwise: You married me for Love.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: And you me for Money: So you have your Reward, and I have mine.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What is it that disturbs you?

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: A Parson.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why, what has he done to you?

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: He has married me. Exit Sir John.

The Devil's in the Fellow I think— I was told before I married him, that thus 'twou●d be; But I thought I had Charms enough to govern him; and that where there was an Estate, a Woman must needs be happy; so my Vanity has deceiv'd me, and my Ambition has made me uneasie. But some comfort still; if one wou'd be revenged of him, these are good times; a Woman may have a Gallant, and a separate maintenance too— The surly Puppy— yet
he's a Fool for't: For hitherto he has been no Monster: But who knows how far he may provoke me. I never lov'd him, yet I have been ever true to him; and that, in spight of all the attacks of Art and Nature upon a poor weak Womans heart, in favour of a Tempting Lover.

Methinks so Noble a Defence as I have made, shou'd be rewarded with a better usage— Or who can tell— Perhaps a good part of what I suffer from my Husband may be a Judgment upon me for my cruelty to my Lover.— Lord with what pleasure cou'd I indulge that thought, were there but a possibility of finding Arguments to make it good. And how do I know but there may— Let me see— What opposes?— My Matrimonial Vow?— Why, what did I Vow: I think I promis'd to be true to my Husband.
Well; and he promis'd to be kind to me.
But he han't kept his Word—

Why then I'm absolv'd from mine— ay, that seems clear to me. The Arguments good between the King and the People, why not between the Husband and the Wife? O, but that Condition was not exprest.— No matter, 'twas understood.

Well, by all I see, If I argue the matter a little longer with my self, I shan't find so many Bug-bears in the way, as I thought I shou'd. Lord what fine notions of Virtue do we Women take up upon the Credit of old foolish Philosophers. Virtue's it's own reward, Virtue's this, Virtue's that;— Virtue's an Ass, and a Gallant's worth forty on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good morrow, Dear Cousin.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Good morrow, Madam; you look pleas'd this morning.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am so.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: With what, pray?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With my Husband.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Drown Husbands; for your's is a provoking Fellow: As he went out just now, I pray'd him to tell me what time of day 'twas: And he ask'd me if I took him for the Church Clock, that was Oblig'd to tell all the Parish.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: He has been saying some good obliging things to me too. In short, Bellinda, he has us'd me so barbarously of late, that I cou'd almost resolve to play the down-right Wife,— and Cuckold him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That wou'd be down-right indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why, after all, there's more to be said for't than you'd Imagine, Child. I know according to the strict Statute Law of Religion, I should do wrong: But if there were a Court of Chancery in Heaven, I'm sure I shou'd cast him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If there were a House of Lords you might.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.l: In either I shou'd infallibly carry my Cause.
Why, he is the first Agressor. Not I.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ay, but you know, we must return Good for Evil.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: That may be a mistake in the Translation—

Prethee be of my opinion, Bellinda; for I'm positive I'm in the right; and if you'll keep up the Prerogative of a Woman, you'll likewise be positive you are in the right, when ever you do any thing you have a mind to. But I shall play the fool, and jest on till I make you begin to think I'm in Earnest

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I sha'n't take the liberty, Madam, to think of any thing that you desire to keep a Secret from me.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Alas, my Dear, I have no Secrets. My heart cou'd never yet confine my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your eyes you mean; for I am sure I have seen them gadding, when your Tongue has been lockt up safe enough.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: My eyes gadding? Prethee after who, Child?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, after one that thinks you hate him, as much as I know you love him.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Constant you mean.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I do so.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Lord, what shou'd put such a thing into your head?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That which puts things into most peoples Heads; Observation.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why, what have you observ'd, in the name of Wonder?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I have observ'd you blush when you meet him; force your self away from him; and then be out of humour with every thing about you: In a word; never was poor Creature so spurr'd on by desire, and so rein'd in with fear!

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: How strong is Fancy!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How weak is Woman

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Prethee, Neice, have a better opinion of your Aunt's Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Dear Aunt, have a better opinion of your Neice's Understanding.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: You'll make me Angry.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You'll make me Laugh.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Then you are resolv'd to persist?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Positively.

sp.speaker: Lady Bel.
sp.p: And all I can say—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Will signifie nothing,

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Tho' I shou'd swear 'twere false—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I shou'd think it true.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Then let us both forgive [kissing her] for we have both offended. I in making a Secret, you in discovering it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Good nature may do much: But you have more reason to forgive one, than I have to pardon t'other.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Bellinda, you have given me so many proofs or your Friendship, that my reserve has been indeed a Crime: But that you may more easily forgive me, Remember, Child, that when our Nature prompts us to a thing, our Honour and Religion have forbid us. We wou'd (were't possible) conceal even from the Soul it self, the knowledge of the Bodies weakness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, I hope, to make your Friend amends, you'll hide nothing from her for the future, tho' the Body shou'd still grow weaker and weaker.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: No, from this moment I have no more reserve; and for a proof of my Repentance, I own, Bellinda, I'm in danger. Merit and Wit assault me from without: Nature and Love solicite me within; my Husbands barbarous usage piques me to revenge; and Sathan catching at the fair occasion, throws in my way that vengeance, which of all Vengeance pleases Women best.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis well Constant don't know the weakness of the Fortifications; for o'my Conscience he'd soon come on to the Assault.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ay, and I'm afraid carry the Town too. But whatever you may have observ'd, I have dissembled so well as to keep him Ignorant. So you see I'm no Coquet, Bellinda: And if you'll follow my advice you'll never be one neither. 'Tis true, Coquettry is one of the main ingredients in the natural Composition of a Woman, and I as well as others, cou'd be well enough pleas'd to see a Crowd of young Fellows, Ogling and Glancing and Watching all occasions to do forty foolish officious things: nay shou'd some of 'em push on, even to Hanging or Drowning: Why— Faith— if I shou'd let pure Woman alone, I shou'd e'en be but too well pleas'd with't.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'll swear 'twou●d tickle me strangely.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: But after all, 'tis a Vicious practice in us, to give the least encouragement but where we design to come to a Conclusion. For 'tis an unreasonable thing, to engage a Man in a Disease which we before-han● resolve we never will apply a Cure to.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis true; but then a Woman must abandon one of the supream Blessings of her Life. For I am fully convinc'd, no Man has half that pleasure in possessing a Mistress, as a Woman has in jilting a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The Happiest Woman then on Earth must be our Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O the Impertinent Composition; she has Vanity and Affectation enough to make her a Ridiculous Original, in spight of all that Art and Nature ever furnisht to any of her Sex before her.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: She concludes all Men her Captives; and whatever Course they take, it serves to confirm her in that opinion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If they shun her, she thinks 'tis modesty, and takes it for a proof of their Passion.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: And if they are rude to her, 'tis Conduct, and done to prevent Town talk.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: When her Folly makes 'em laugh, she thinks they are pleas'd with her Wit..

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: And when her impertinence makes 'em Dull, Concludes they are jealous of her favours.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: All their Actions and their Words, she takes for granted, aim at her.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: And pities all other Women, because she thinks they envy her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray, out of pity to our selves, let us find a better Subject, for I am weary of this. Do you think your Husband inclin'd to Jealousie?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O, no; he do's not love me well enough for that.
Lord how wrong Men's Maxims are. They are seldom jealous of their Wives, unless they are very fond of 'em; whereas they ought to consider the Womans inclinations, for there depends their Fate.
Well, Men may talk; but they are not so Wise as we— that's certain.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: At least in our Affairs.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Nay, I believe we shou'd out do 'em in the business of the State too: For me thinks they Do and Undo, and make but mad work on't

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why then don't we get into the Intrigues of Government as well as they?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Because we have Intrigues of our own, that make us more sport, Child. And so let's in and consider of 'em. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lady Fancyfull, Madamoiselle and Cornet.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: How do I look this morning?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Your Ladyship looks very ill, truly.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Lard how ill-natur'd thou art, Cornet, to tell me so, tho the thing should be true. Don't you know that I have humility enough to be but too easily out of Conceit with my self. Hold the Glass; I dare swear that will have more manners than you have▪ Madamoiselle, let me have your opinion too.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: My opinion pe, Matam, dat your Ladyship never look so well in your Life.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Well, the French are the prettiest obliging People, they say the most acceptable, well manner'd things— and never flatter.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Your Ladyship say great Justice inteed.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Nay every thing's Just in my House but Cornet. The very Looking-Glass gives her the Dementi. But I'm almost afraid it flatters me, it makes me look so very engaging. Looking affectedly in the Glass.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Inteed, Matam, your Face pe hansomer den all de Looking-Glass in tee World, croyiez moy.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: But is it possible my Eyes can be so languishing— and so very full of fire?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Matam, if de Glass was burning Glass, I believe your Eyes set de fire in de House.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: You may take that Night-Gown, Madamoiselle; get out of the Room Cornet; I can't endure you. This Wench methinks does look so unsufferably ugly. Exit Cor.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Every ting look ugly Matam, dat stand by your Latiship.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: No really, Madamoiselle, methinks you look mighty prety.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Ah Matam; de Moon have to Eclat, ven de Sun appear.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: O pretty Expression. Have you ever been in Love, Madamoiselle?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Ouy, Matam. sighing.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: And were you, belov'd again?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: No Matam. sighing

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: O ye Gods, What an Unfortunate Creature should I be in such a Case. But nature has made me Nice for my own defence; I'm Nice, strangely Nice, Madamoiselle; I believe were the merit of whole mankind bestow'd upon one single Person, I should still think the Fellow wanted something, to make it worth my while to take notice of him: And yet I could Love; nay fondly Love, were it possible to have a thing made on purpose for me: For I'm not cruel, Madamoiselle, I'm only Nice.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Ah Matam, I wish I was fine Gentelman for your sake. I do all de ting in de World to get leetel way into your heart. I make Song, I make Verse, I give you de Serenade, I give great many Present to Madamoiselle, I no eat, I no sleep, I be lean, I be mad, I hang my self, I drown my self? Ah ma Chere Dame, Que je vous Aimerois. Embracing her.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Well the French have strange obliging ways with 'em; you may take those two pair of Gloves Madamoiselle.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Me humbly tanke my sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam here's a Letter for your Ladyship by the Penny-post.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Some new Conquest I'll warrant you. For without Vanity I look'd extreamly clear last night, when I went to the Park.
O agreeable. Here's a new Song made of me. And ready set too. O thou Welcome thing. (Kissing it) Call Pipe hither, she shall Sing it instantly.
Here, Sing me this new Song, Pipe.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: FLy, fly, you happy Shepherds, fly,
Avoid Philira's Charms;
The rigour of her heart denies
The Heaven that's in her Arms.
Ne'er hope to gaze and then retire,
Nor yielding, to be blest:
Nature who form'd her Eyes of Fire,
Of Ice Compos'd her Breast.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Yet, lovely Maid, this once believe
A slave, whose Zeal you move:
The Gods Alas, your youth deceive;
Their Heaven consists in Love.
In spight of all the thanks you owe,
You may Reproach 'em this,
That where they did their Form bestow
They have deny'd their Bliss.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Well, there may be faults, Madamoiselle, but the Design is so very obliging, 'twou'd be a matchless Ingratitude in me to discover 'em.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Ma foy Matam, I tink de Gentelman's Song tell you de trute. If you never Love, you never be Happy— Ah— que I' aime l' amour moy.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam here's another Letter for your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: 'Tis thus I am importun'd every morning, Madamoiselle. Pray how do the French Ladies when they are thus Accablées?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Matam, dey never Complain. Au Contraire. When one Frense Laty have got hundred Lover— Den she do all she can— to get hundred more.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Well, strike me dead, I think they have Le gout bon. For 'tis an unutterable pleasure to be ador'd by all the Men, and envy'd by all the Women— Yet I'll swear I'm concerned at the Torture I give 'em. Lard, why was I form'd to make the whole Creation uneasy? But let me read my Letter.

body.p: If you have a mind to hear of your faults, instead of being praised for your Virtues, take the pains to walk in the Green walk in St. Iames's with your Woman an hour hence. You'll there meet one, who hates you for some things, as he cou'd love you for Others, and therefore is willing to endeavour your Reformation— If you come to the Place I mention, you'll know who I am; if you don't, you never shall, so take your Choice.

sp.p: This is strangely Familiar, Madamoiselle; now have I a provoking Fancy to know who this Impudent fellow is.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Den take your Scarf and your Mask, and go to de Rendezvous De Frense Laty do iustement comme sa.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Rendezvous! What, Rendezvous with a man; Madamoiselle.

sp.speaker: Madam
sp.p: Eh, pourquoy non?

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: What? and a man perhaps I never saw in my Life

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Tant mieux: c'est donc quelque chose de nouveau.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Why, how do I know what designs he may have. He may intend to Ravish me for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Ravish?— Bagatelle. I would fain see one Impudent Rogue Ravish Madamoiselle; Ouy, je le voadrois.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: O but my Reputation, Madamoiselle, my Reputation, a● ma Chere Reputation.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Matam;— Quand on l' a une fois perdue— On n'en est plus embarassee.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Fe Madamoiselle, Fe: Reputation is a Jewel.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Qui coute bien chere Matam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Why sure you wou'd not Sacrifice your Honor to your Pleasure?

sp.speaker: Madam
sp.p: Je suis Philosophe.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Bless me how you talk. Why what if Honour be a burden, Madamoiselle, must it not be born?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Chaque un a sa fason— quand quelque chose m' incommode moy je m' en defais, Vite.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Get you gone you little naughty French woman you, I vow and swear I must turn you out of doors if you talk thus.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Turn me out of doors?— turn your self out of doors and go see what de Gentelman have to say to you Tennez. Voila [giving her her things hastily] vostre Esharpe, Voila vostre Quoife, Voila vostre Masque, Voila tout.

Hey, Mercure, Coquin; Call one Chair for Matam, and one oder (Calling within.) for me, Va t'en Vite. Turning to her Lady and helping her on hastily with her things. Alons, Matam; depechez vous donc. Mon Dieu quelles scrupules.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Well, for once, Madamoiselle, I'll follow your Advice, out of the intemperate desire I have to know who this ill bred Fellow is. But I have too much Delicatesse, to make a Practice on it.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Belle chose Vraiment que la Delicatesse, lors qu' il s'agit dese devertir.— a za— Vous Voila equipée parto●ns.— He bien?— q' avez vous donc?

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: I' ay peur.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: I' n'en ay point moy.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: I dare not go.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Demeurez donc.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Je suis Poltrone.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Tant pis pour Vous

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Curiosity's a wicked Devil.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: C'est une Charmante Sainte.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: It ruin'd our first Parents.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Elle a bien diverti leurs Enfants.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: L' honneur est contre.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Le plaisir est pour.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Must I then go?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Must you go?— must you eat, must you drink, must you sleep, must you live? De nature bid you do one, de nature bid you do toder. Vous me ferez enrager.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: But when reason corrects nature, Madamoiselle.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Elle est donc bien Insolente C'est sa soeur aisnée.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Do you then prefer your nature to your reason, Madamoiselle.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Ouy da.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Pourquoy?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Because my nature make me merry, my reason make me mad.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: Ah la Mechante Fransoise.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Ah la Belle Angloise, forcing her Lady off.

div.trailer: The End of the first Act.

div.head: ACT the Second.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: WEll, I vow, Madamoiselle I'm strangely impatient to know who this confident Fellow is. Enter Heartfree. Look, there's Heartfree. But sure it can't be him, he's a profess'd Woman-hater. Yet who knows what my wicked Eyes may have done?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Il nous approche, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis he: Now will he be most intolerably Cavalier, tho' he should be in love with me.

sp.speaker: Heartf.
sp.p: Madam, I'm your humble Servant: I perceive you have more Humility and Good-nature than I thought you had.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: What you attribute to Humility and Good-nature, Sir, may perhaps be only due to Curiosity. I had a mind to know who 'twas had ill manners enough to write that Letter.

sp.speaker: Heartf.
sp.p: Well, and now, I hope, you are satisfied.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: I am so, Sir; good b'w'y to ye.

sp.speaker: Heartf.
sp.p: Nay, hold there; tho' you have done your Business, I han't done mine: By your Ladiship's leave, we must have one moments prattle together. Have you a mind to be the prettiest Woman about Town, or not? How she stares upon me! What! this passes for an impertinent Question with you now, because you think you are so already.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Pray Sir, let me ask you a Question in my turn: By what right do you pretend to examine me?

sp.speaker: Heartf.
sp.p:
By the same right that the Strong govern the Weak, because I have you in my power; for you cannot get so quickly to
your Coach, but I shall have time enough to make you hear every thing I have to say to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: These are strange Liberties you take, Mr. Heartfree.

sp.speaker: Heartf.
sp.p: They are so, Madam, but there's no help for it; for know, that I have a Design upon you.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Upon me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Yes; and one that will turn to your Glory and my Comfort, if you will but be a little wiser than you use to be.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Let me see,— Your Vanity, Madam, I take to be about some eight degrees higher than any Womans in the Town, let t'other be who she will; and my Indifference is naturally about the same pitch. Now, cou'd you find the way to turn this Indifference into Fire and Flames, methinks your Vanity ought to be satisfied; and this, perhaps, you might bring about upon pretty reasonable terms.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: And pray at what rate would this Indifference be bought off, if one should have so deprav'd an Appetite to desire it?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Why, Madam, to drive a Quaker's Bargain, and make but one word with you, if I do part with it,— you must lay me down— your Affectation.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: My Affectation, Sir!

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Why, I ask you nothing but what you may very well spare.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: You grow rude, Sir. Come, Madamoiselle, 'tis high time to be gone.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Alons, alons, alons.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: (stopping 'em) Nay, you may as well stand still for hear me, you shall, walk which way you please.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: What mean you, sir?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: I mean to tell you, that you are the most ungrateful Woman upon Earth.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Ungrateful! To who?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: To Nature.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Why, what has Nature done for me?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p:
What you have undone by Art. It made you handsom; it gave you Beauty to a Miracle, a Shape without a fault, Wit enough to make 'em relish, and so turn'd you loose to your own Discretion; which has made such Work with you, that you are become
the Pity of our Sex, and the Jest of your own. There is not a Feature in your Face, but you have found the way to teach it some affected Convulsion; your Feet, your Hands, your very Fingers ends, are directed never to move without some ridiculous Air or other; and your Language is a suitable Trumpet, to draw Peoples Eyes upon the Raree-show.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: (aside) Est ce qu'on fais l'amour en Angleterre comme sa?

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: (aside) Now could I cry for madness, but that I know he'd laugh at me for it.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Now do you hate me for telling you the Truth; but that's because you don't believe it is so: for were you once convinc'd of that, you'd reform for your own sake. But 'tis as hard to perswade a Woman to quit any thing that makes her ridiculous, as 'tis to prevail with a Poet to see a Fault in his own Play.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Every Circumstance of nice Breeding must needs appear ridiculous to one who has so natural an Antipathy to good Manners.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: But suppose I could find the means to convince you, That the whole World is of my Opinion, and that those who flatter and commend you, do it to no other intent, but to make you persevere in your Folly, that they may continue in their Mirth.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Sir, tho' you and all that World you talk of, should be so impertinently officious, as to think to perswade me, I don't know how to behave my self, I should still have Charity enough for my own Understanding, to believe my self in the right, and all you in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Le voila mort. Exeunt Lady Fanc. and Madamoiselle.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: (gazing after her) There her single Clapper has publish'd the sense of the whole Sex.

Well, this once I have endeavour'd to wash the Blackamoor white; but henceforward I'll sooner undertake to teach Sincerity to a Courtier, Generosity to an Usurer, Honesty to a Lawyer, nay, Humility to a Divine, than Discretion to a Woman I see has once set her Heart upon playing the Fool.
‛ Morrow, Constant.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Good morrow, Iack; What are you doing here this morning?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Doing! guess if thou canst.
Why, I have been endeavouring to perswade my Lady Fanciful, that she's the foolishest Woman about Town.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: A pretty Endeavour truly.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: I have told her in as plain English as I could speak, both what the Town says of her, and what I think of her. In short, I have us'd her as an Absolute King would do Magna Charta.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And how does she take it?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: As Children do Pills; bite 'em, but can't swallow 'em.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But, prithee, what has put it in your Head, of all Mankind, to turn Reformer?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Why, one thing was, the Morning hung upon my Hands, I did not know what to do with my self. And another was, That as little as I care for Women, I could not see with patience one that Heaven had taken such wondrous pains about, be so very industrious, to make her self the Iack Pudding of the Creation.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well, now could I almost wish to see my cruel Mistriss make the self-same use of what Heaven has done for her, that so I might be cur'd of a Disease that makes me so very uneasie; for Love, Love is the Devil, Heartfree.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: And why do you let the Devil govern you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Because I have more Flesh and Blood than Grace and Self-denial. My dear, dear Mistriss, ' d Sdeath! that so genteel a Woman should be a Saint, when Religion's out of fashion!

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Nay, she's much in the wrong truly; but who knows how far Time and Good Example may prevail?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O! they have play'd their Parts in vain already: 'Tis now two Years since that damn'd fellow her Husband invited me to his Wedding; and there was the first time I saw that charming Woman, whom I have lov'd ever since, more than e'er a Martyr did his Soul; but she's cold, my Friend, still cold as the Northern Star.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: So are all Women by Nature, which makes 'em so willing to be warmed.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O, don't prophane the Sex; prithee think 'em all Angels for her sake, for she's virtuous, even to a fault.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: A Lover's Head is a good accountable thing truly; he adores his Mistriss for being virtuous, and yet is very angry with her, because she won't be lewd.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well, the only Relief I expect in my Misery, is to see thee some day or other as deeply engag'd as my self, which will force me to be merry in the midst of all my Misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: That day will never come, be assur'd, Ned: Not but that I can pass a Night with a Woman, and for the time, perhaps, make my self as good sport as you can do. Nay, I can court a Woman too, call her Nymph, Angel, Goddess, what you please; but here's the Difference 'twixt you and I: I perswade a Woman she's an Angel; she perswades you she's one.
Prithee let me tell you how I avoid falling in love; that which serves me for Prevention, may chance to serve you for a Cure.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well, use the Ladies moderately then, and I'll hear you.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: That using 'em moderately undoes us all; but I'll use 'em justly, and that you ought to be satisfied with.

I always consider a Woman, not as the Taylor, the Shoo-maker, the Tire-woman, the Sempstress, (and which is more than all that) the Poet makes her; but I consider her as pure Nature has contriv'd her, and that more strictly than I should have done our old Grandmother Eve, had I seen her naked in the Garden; for I consider her turn'd inside out. Her Heart well examin'd, I find there Pride, Vanity, Covetousness, Indiscretion, but above all things, Malice; Plots eternally aforging, to destroy one anothers Reputations, and as honestly to charge the Levity of Mens Tongues with the Scandal; hourly Debates how to make poor Gentlemen in love with 'em, with no other intent, but to use 'em like Dogs when they have done; a constant Desire of doing more mischief, and an everlasting War, waged against Truth and Good-nature.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, an admirable Composition truly.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Then for her Outside, I consider it meerly as an Outside; She has a thin Tiffany covering over just such Stuff as you and I are made on.

As for her Motion, her Meen, her Airs, and all those Tricks, I know they affect you mightily. If you should see your Mistriss at a Coronation, dragging her Peacock's Train, with all her state and insolence about her, 'twould strike you with all the awful thoughts that Heaven it self could pretend to from you; whereas I turn the
whole matter into a Jest, and suppose her strutting in the self-same stately manner, with nothing on but her Stays, and her under scanty 〈◊〉 Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Hold thy prophane Tongue, for I'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: What you'll love on then?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, to Eternity.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Yet you have no Hopes at all.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Nay, the Resolution may be discreet enough; perhaps you have found out some new Philosophy, That Love's like Virtue, its own Reward: so you and your Mistriss will be as well content at a distance, as others that have less Learning are in coming together.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No; but if she should prove kind at last, my dear Heartfree. Embracing him.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Nay, prithee don't take me for your Mistriss, for Lovers are very troublesome.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well, who knows what Time may do?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: And just now he was sure Time could do nothing.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yet not one kind Glance in Two Years, is somewhat strange.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Not strange at all; she don't like you, that's all the business.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Prithee don't distract me.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Nay, you are a good handsome young Fellow, she might use you better: Come, will you go see her? perhaps she may have chang'd her mind; there's some Hopes as long as she's a Woman.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O, 'tis in vain to visit her: sometimes to get a sight of her, I visit that Beast her Husband, but she certainly finds some Pretence to quit the Room as soon as I enter.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: It's much she don't tell him you have made Love to her too, for that's another good-natur'd thing usual amongst Women, in which they have several Ends.
Sometimes 'tis to recommend their Virtue, that they may be lewd with the greater security.

Sometimes 'tis to make their Husbands fight in hopes they may be killed, when their Affairs require it should be so. But most commonl● 'tis to engage two men in a Quarrel, that they may have the Credit of being fought for; and if the Lover's kill'd in the business, they cry, Poor Fellow! he had ill Luck.— And so they go to Cards.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Thy Injuries to Women are not to be fo●rgiven. Look to't if ever thou dost fall into their hands—

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: They can't use me worse than they do you, that speak well of 'em.
Coelo! here comes the Knight.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: How does all your Family?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Pox o' my Family.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How does your Lady? I han't seen her abroad a good while.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Do! I don't know how she does, not I; she was well enough yesterday: I ha'n't been at home to night.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What! were you out of Town!

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Out of Town! no, I was drinking.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You are a true Englishman; Don't know your own Happiness? if I were married to such a Woman, I would not be from her a Night for all the Wine in France.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Not from her!— Oons,— what a time should a man have of that!

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Why, there's no Division, I hope?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: No; but there's a Conjunction, and that's worse; a Pox o' the Parson.— Why the plague don't you two marry? I fansie I look like the Devil to you.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Why, you don't think you have Horns, do you?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: No; I believe my Wife's Religion will keep her honest.

sp.speaker: Heartfr
sp.p: And what will make her keep her Religion?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Persecution; and therefore she shall have it.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Have a care Knight, Women are tender things.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: And yet, methinks, 'tis a hard matter to break their Hearts.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Fie, fie; you have one of the best Wives in the World, and yet you seem the most uneasie Husband.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Best Wives!— the Woman's well enough, she has no Vice that I know of, but she's a Wife, and— damn a Wife; if I were married to a Hogshead of Claret, Matrimony would make me hate it.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Why did you marry then? you were old enough to know your own mind.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Why did I marry! I married because I had a mind to lie with her, and she would not let me.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Why did not you ravish her?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Yes, and so have hedg'd my self into forty Quarrels with her Relations, besides buying my Pardon: But more than a● that, you must know, I was afraid of being damn'd in those days, for I kept sneaking cowardly Company, Fellows that went to Church, said Grace to their Meat, and had not the least Tincture of Quality about 'em.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: But I think you are got into a better Gang now.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.p: Zoons, Sir, my Lord Rake and I are Hand and Glove, I believe we may get our Bones broke together to night; Have you a mind to share a Frolick?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Not I truly, my Talent lies to softer Exercises.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: What? a Doune-bed and a Strumpet?
A Pox of Venery, I say.
Will you come and drink with me this Afternoon?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I can't drink to day, but we'll come and sit an hour with you if you will.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: Phugh, Pox, sit an hour!
Why can't you drink?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Because I'm to see my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Why, do you use to tell?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: So won't I.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Because 'tis a Secret.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: Wou'd my Wife knew it, 'twould be no Secret long.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Why, do you think she can't keep a Secret?

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: No more than she can keep Lent.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.l: Prithee tell it her to try, Constant.

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: No, prithee don't, that I mayn't be plagu'd with it.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I'll hold you a Guinea you don't make her tell it you:

sp.speaker: Sir J.
sp.l: I'll hold you a Guinea I do.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.l: Why I'll beg her not to tell it me.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.l: Nay, if any thing do's it, that will.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: But do you think, Sir?—

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p:
Oons, Sir, I think a Woman and a Secret, are the two impertinentest Themes in the Universe. Therefore pray let's hear no more, of my Wife nor your Mistress. Damn 'em both with
all my Heart, and every thing else that Daggles a Petticoat, except four Generous Whores, with Betty Sands at the head of 'em, who were drunk with my Lord Rake and I, ten times in a Fortnight. Exit Sir John.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Here's a dainty fellow for you. And the veriest Coward too. But his usage of his Wife makes me ready to stab the Villain.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Lovers are short sighted: All their Senses run into that of feeling. This proceeding of his is the only thing on Earth can make your Fortune. If any thing can prevail with her to accept of a Gallant 'tis his ill usage of her; for Women will do more for revenge than they'll do four the Gospel.
Prethee take heart, I have great hopes for you, and since I can't bring you quite off of her, I'll endeavour to bring you quite on; for a whining Lover, is the damn'd'st Companion upon Earth.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My Dear Friend, flatter me a little more with these hopes: for whilst they prevail I have Heaven within me, and cou'd melt with joy.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Pray no melting yet: let things go farther first. This afternoon perhaps we shall make some advance. In the mean while, let's go Dine at Locket's, and let hope get you a Stomach. Exeunt▪

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Did you ever see any thing so Importune, Madamoiselle?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Inteed Matam, to say de trute, he want leetel good breeding.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Good breeding? He wants to be cain'd, Madamoiselle: an Insolent Fellow.

And yet let me expose my Weakness, 'tis the only Man on earth I cou'd resolve to dispence my Favours on, were he but a fine Gentleman. Well; did Men but know how deep an Impression a fine Gentleman makes in a Lady's heart, they would reduce all their studies to that of good breeding alone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Madam here's Mr. Treble. He has brought home the Verses your Ladyship made, and gave him to set.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.l: O let him come in by all means.
Now, Madamoiselle, am I going to be unspeakably happy.
So Mr. Treble, you have set my little Dialogue?

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and I hope your Ladyship will be pleased with it.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: O, no doubt on't; for really Mr. Treble, you set all things to a Wonder: But your Musick is in particular Heavenly, when you have my words to cloath in't.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: Your words themselves, Madam, have so much Musick in 'em they inspire me.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Nay, now you make me blush, Mr. Treble; but pray let's hear what you have done.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: You shall, Madam.

div.head: A Song to be Sung between a Man and a Woman.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: AH Lovely Nymph, the world 's on Fire:
Viel, Veil those cruel Eyes.

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: The World may then in Flames expire,
And boast that so it Dies.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: But when all Mortals are destroyd,
Who then shall Sing your Praise?

sp.speaker: W.
sp.l: Those who are fit to be employ'd:
The Gods shall Altars raise.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: How do's your Ladship like it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Rapture, Rapture, Mr. Treble, I'm all Rapture. O Wit and Art, what power you have when joyn'd. I must needs tell you the Birth of this Little Dialogue, Mr. Treble. It's Father was a Dream, and it's Mother was the Moon. I dreamt, that by an unanimous Vote, I was chosen Queen of that Pale World. And that the first time I appear'd upon my Throne,— all my Subjects fell in Love with me. Just then I wak'd: and seeing Pen, Ink and Paper lie idle upon the Table, I slid into my Morning Gown, and writ this in promptu.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: So I guess the Dialogue, Madam, is suppos'd to be between your Majesty and your first Minister of State.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Just: he as Minister advises me to trouble my head about the wellfare of my Subjects; which I as Soveraign, find a very impertinent proposal. But is the Town so Dull, Mr. Treble, it affords us never another New Song?

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: Madam, I have one in my Pocket, came out but yesterday, if your Ladyship pleases to let Mrs. Pipe Sing it.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: By all means. Here Pipe. Make what Musique you can of this Song, here.

lg.l: NOT an Angel dwells above
Half so fair as her I Love:
Heaven knows how she'll receive me:
If she smiles, I'm blest indeed
If she frowns, I'm quickly freed;
Heaven knows, she ne'er can grieve me.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: None can Love her more than I,
Yet she ne'er shall make me die.
If my flame can never warm her;
Lasting Beauty, I'll adore,
I shall never Love her more,
Cruelty will so deform her.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Very well: This is Heartfree's Poetry without question.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: Won't your Ladiship please to sing your self this morning?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: O Lord, Mr. Treble, my cold is still so Barbarous, to refuse me that pleasure; He he hem.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: I'm very sorry for it, Madam: Methinks all Mankind shou'd turn Physicians for the Cure on't.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Why truly to give mankind their due; There's few that know me, but have offer'd their Remedy.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: They have reason, Madam, for I know no body Sings so near a Cherubin as your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: What I do I owe chiefly to your skill and care, Mr. Treble. People do better me indeed, that I have a voice and a je ne scai quoy in the Conduct of it, that will make Musick of any thing. And truly I begin to believe so, since what happen'd t'other night: would you think it, Mr. Treble; walking pretty late in the Park, (for I often walk late in the Park, Mr. Treble;) A whim took me to sing Chivy-Chase, and would you believe it? Next morning I had three Copies of Verses, and six Billet-doux at my Levee upon it.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: And without all dispute you deserv'd as many more, Madam, are there any further Commands for your Ladyship's humble Servant?

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Nothing more at this time, Mr. Treble. But I shall expect you here every morning for this Month, to sing my little matter there to me. I'll reward you for your pains.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Good morrow, sweet Mr. Treble.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.p: Your Ladyships most obedient Servant. Exit Treb.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Will your Ladyship please to dine yet? Exit. Serv.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Yes: let 'em serve.
Sure this Heartfree has bewitch'd me, Madamoiselle.
You can't imagine how odly he mixt himself in my thoughts during my Rapture e'en now. I vow 'tis a thousand pities he is not more polished. Don't you think so?

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Matam. I tink it so great pity, dat if I was in your Ladyship place, I take him home in my House, I lock him up in my Closet, and I never let him go till I teach him every ting dat fine Laty expect from fine Gentelman.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Why truly I believe, I shou'd soon subdue his Brutality; for without doubt, he has a strange penchant to grow fond of me, in spight of his Aversion to the Sex, else he wou'd ne'er have taken so much pains about me. Lord how proud wou'd some poor Creatures be of such a Conquest? But I alas, I don't know how to receive as a favour, what I take to be so infinitely my due But what shall I do to new mould him, Madamoiselle? for till then he's my utter aversion.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: Matam, you must laugh at him in all de place dat you meet him, and turn into de ridicule all he say and all he do.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: Why truly Satyr has been ever of wonderous use, to reform ill manners. Besides 'tis my particular Talent to ridicule folks. I can be severe; strangely severe, when I will, Madamoiselle.— Give me the Pen and Ink:— I find my self whimsicall— I'll write to him.
— or I ll let it alone, and be severe upon him that way. Sitting down to write. Rising up again.
— Yet active severity is better than passive. Sitting down.
— 'Tis as good let alone too, for every lash I give him, perhaps he'll take for a favour. Rising
— Yet 'tis a thousand pities so much Siting.
— Satyr should be lost. Siting.
— But if it shou'd have a wrong effect upon him 'twould distract me. Rising.
— Well I must write tho' after all. Siting.
— Or I'll let it alone which is the same thing. Rising.

sp.speaker: Madam.
sp.p: La Voilá determinée. Exeunt.

div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT the Third.
div.stage: SCENE Opens. Sir Iohn, Lady Brute and Bellinda rising from the Table.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: HEre; take away the things: I expect Company. But first bring me a Pipe; I'll smoak. to a Servant.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Lord, Sir Iohn, I wonder you won't leave that nasty Custom.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Prithee don't be Impertinent.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: to Lady. I wonder who those are he expects this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I'd give the World to know: Perhaps 'tis Constant; he comes here sometimes; If it does prove him, I'm resolved I'll share the visit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: We'll send for our Work and sit here.

sp.speaker: Lady B
sp.p: He'll choak us with his Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nothing will choak us, when we are doing what we have a mind to. Lovewell

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Here; bring my Cousin's work and mine hither

div.stage: Exit Love. and Re-enters with their Work.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Whu; Pox, can't you work somewhere else?
We shall be carefull not to disturb you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Pipe would make you too thoughtfull, Unkle, if you were left alone; Our prittle prattle will Cure your Spleen.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Will it so, Mrs. Pert? Now I believe it will so increase it sitting and smoaking. I shall take my own House for a Paper-Mill.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: to Bel. aside Don't let's mind him; let him say what he will.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: A Woman's Tongue a cure for the Spleen— Oons— aside. If a Man had got the Headach, they'd be for applying the same Remedy.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: You have done a great deal Bellinda since yesterday.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes, I have work'd very hard; how do you like it?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O' 'tis the prettiest Fringe in the World. Well Cousin you have the happiest fancy. Prithee advice me about altering my Crimson Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: A Pox o' your Petticoat; here's such a prating a man can't digest his own thoughts for you.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Don't answer him. Aside
Well, what do you advise me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why really I would not alter it at all.
Methinks 'tis very pretty as it is.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ay that's true: But you know one grows weary of the prettiest things in the world, when one has had 'em long.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Yes, I have taught her that.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Shall we provoke him a little?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.l: With all my heart.
Bellinda, don't you long to be Married?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why there are some things in't I could like well enough.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What do you think you shou'd dislike?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Husband a hundred to one else.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O ye wicked wretch: Sure you don't speak as you think.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes I do: Especially if he smoak'd Tobacco. He looks earnestly at 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why that many times takes off worse smells.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then he must smell very ill indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: So some Men will, to keep their Wives from coming near 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then those Wives shou'd Cuckold 'em at a Distance.

div.stage: He rises in a fury, throws his Pipe at 'em and drives 'em out. As they run off, Constant and Heartfree enter. Lady B. runs against Constant.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Oons get you gone up stairs you confederating Strumpets you, or I'll Cuckold you with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O Lord he'll beat us, he'll beat us. Dear, Dear Mr. Constant save us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: I'll Cuckold you with a Pox.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Heavens, Sir Iohn, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Sure if Woman had been ready created, the Devil, instead of being kick'd down into Hell, had been Married.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why what new plague have you found now?

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Why these two Gentlewomen did but hear me say, I expected you here this afternoon; upon which, they presently resolved to take up the Roon, o' purpose to plague me and my Friends.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Was that all? why we shou'd have been glad of their Company.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Then I should have been weary of yours. For I can't relish both together. They found fault with my smoaking Tobacco too; and said Men stunk. But I have a good mind— to say something.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No, nothing against the Ladies pray.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Split the Ladies. Come, will you sit down? Give us some Wine, Fellow:
You won't smoak?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No nor drink neither at this time, I must ask your pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: What, this Mistress of yours runs in your head; I'll warrant it's some such squeamish Minx as my Wife, that's grown so dainty of late, she finds fault even with a Dirty shirt.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: That a woman may do, and not be very dainty neither.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Pox o' the women, let's drink. Come, you shall take one Glass, tho' I send for a Box of Lozenges to sweeten your mouth after it.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay if one Glass will satisfy you I'll drink it without putting you to that expence.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Why that's honest. Fill some Wine, Sirrah: So, Here's to you Gentlemen— A Wife's the Devil. To your being both married They drink

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: O your most humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Well? how do you like my Wine?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis very good indeed.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: 'Tis Admirable.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Then give us t'other Glass.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
No, pray excuse us now. We'll come another time, and
then we won't spare it.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: This one Glass and no more. Come: It shall be your Mistresses health: And that's a great Compliment from me, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And 'tis a very obliging one to me: So give us the Glasses.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: So: Let her live. Sir John Coughs in the Glass.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And be kind.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What's the matter? does't go the wrong way?

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: If I had love enough to be jealous, I shou'd take this for an ill Omen. For I never drank my Wives health in my life, but I puk'd in the Glass.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O she's too Virtuous to make a Reasonable man jealous.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Pox of her Virtue. If I could but catch her Adulterating I might be devorc'd from her by Law.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And so pay her a yearly Pension, to be a distinguish'd Cuckold.
Sir, There's my Lord Rake, Colonel Bully, and some other Gentlemen at the Blew-Posts, desire your Company.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Cods so, we are to Consult about playing the Devil to night.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Well we won't hinder business.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Methinks I don't know how to leave you tho'. But for once I must make bold- Or look you: may be the Conference mayn't last long; so if you'll wait here half an hour, or an hour; if I don't come then,— why then— I won't come at all.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: to Const. A good modest proposition truly: Aside.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But let's accept on't however. Who knows what may happen.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Well Sir, to shew you how fond we are of your Company we'll expect your return as long as we can.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Nay, may be I mayn't stay at all: But business you know must be done. So your Servant— Or hark you: If you have a mind to take a frisk with us, I have an interest with my Lord, I can easily introduce you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We are much beholding to you, but for my part I'm engaged another way.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: What? To your Mistress I'll warrant. Prithee leave your nasty Punk to entertain her self with her own Lewd thoughts, and make one with us to Night.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis business that is to employ me.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And me; and business must be done you know.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Ay; Womens business, tho' the world were consum'd for't.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Farewell Beast: And now my Dear Friend, wou'd my Mistress be but as Complaisant as some mens Wives, who think it a piece of good breeding to receive the visits of their Husbands Friends in his absence.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why for your sake I could forgive her, tho' she should be so Complaisant to receive something else in his absence. But what way shall we invent to see her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O ne'er hope it: Invention will prove as Vain as Wishes.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: What do you think now, Friend?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I think I shall swoon.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I'll speak first then, whilst you fetch breath.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: We think our selves oblig'd Gentlemen, to come and return you thanks for your Knight Errantry. We were just upon being devour'd by the Fiery Dragon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did not his fumes almost knock you down, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Truly Ladies, we did undergo some hardships, and should have done more, if some greater Hero's than our selves hard by had not diverted him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Tho' I'm glad of the Service, you are pleased to say we have done you; yet I'm sorry we cou'd do it no other way, than by making our selves privy, to what you wou'd perhaps have kept a secret.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: For Sir Iohn's part, I suppose be design'd it no secret since he made so much noise. And for my self, truly I am not much concern'd, since 'tis fallen only into this▪ Gentleman's hands and yours; who I have many reasons to believe, will neither interpret nor report any thing to my disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Your good opinion, Madam, was what I fear'd, I never cou'd have merited.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Your fears were vain then, Sir, for I am just to every body.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Prithee, Constant, what is't you do to get the Ladies good Opinions; for I'm a Novice at it?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, will you give me leave to instruct you?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Yes, that I will with all my Soul, Madam.

sp.speaker: ●ell.
sp.p: Why then you must never be slovenly, never be out of humor, fare well and cry Roast-meat; smoak Tobacco, nor drink but when you are a-dry.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: That's hard.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, if you take his Bottle from him, you break his Heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, is it possible the Gentleman can love Drinking?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Only by way of Antidote.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Against what, pray?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Against Love, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Br.
sp.p: Are you afraid of being in Love, Sir?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: I should, if there were any danger of it.

sp.speaker: Lady Br.
sp.p: Pray why so?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Because I always had an aversion to being us'd like a Dog.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why truly, men in love are seldom us'd better.

sp.speaker: Lady Br.
sp.p: But was you never in love, Sir?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: No, I thank Heaven, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray where got you your Learning then?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: From other Peoples Expence.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's being a Spunger, Sir, which is scarce honest; if you'd buy some Experience with your own Mony, as 'twould be fairlyer got, so 'twould stick longer by you.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Madam, here's my Lady Fancyful, to wait upon your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Lady Br.
sp.p: Shield me, kind Heaven, what an inundation of Impertinence is here coming upon us!

div.stage: Enter Lady Fancyful, who runs first to Lady Brute, then to Bellinda, kissing 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: My dear Lady Brute, and sweet Bellinda! methinks 'tis an Age since I saw you.

sp.speaker: Lady Br.
sp.p: Yet 'tis but three days; sure you have pass'd your time very ill, it seems so long to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Why really, to confess the Truth to you, I am so everlastingly fatigu'd with the Addresses of Unfortunate Gentlemen, that were it not for the extravagancy of the Example, I should e'en tear out these wicked Eyes with my own Fingers, to make both my self and Mankind easie. What think you on't, Mr. Heartfree, for I take you to be my faithful Adviser?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Why truly, Madam,— I think— every Project that is for the Good of Mankind, ought to be encourag'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Then I have your Consent, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: To do whatever you please, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: You had a much-more limited Complaisance this Morning, Sir. Would you believe it, Ladies? The Gentleman has been so exceeding generous, to tell me of above fifty Faults, in less time than it was well possible for me to commit two of 'em.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why truly, Madam, my Friend there is apt to be something familiar with the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: He is indeed, Sir; but he's wondrous charitable with it; he has had the Goodness to design a Reformation, even down to my Fingers ends.

'Twas thus, I think, Sir, you would have Opening her Fingers in an awkward manner. had 'em stand.— My Eyes too he did not like: How was't you would have directed 'em? Thus, I think. Staring at him. Then there was something amiss in my Gate too, I don't know well how 'twas; but as I take it, he would have had me walk like him. Pray, Sir, do me the Favour to take a turn or two about the Room, that the Company may see you.— He's sullen, Ladies, and wont: But, to make short, and give you as true an Idea as I can of the matter, I think 'twas much about this Figure in general, he would have moulded me to: But I was an obstinate She walks aukwardly about, having and looking ungainly, when changes on a sadden to the extremity of her vsual Affectation. Woman, and could not resolve to make my self Mistriss of his Heart, by growing as aukward as his Fancy.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Just thus Women do, when Here Constant and Lady Brute talk together apart. they think we are in love with 'em, or when they are so with us.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: 'Twould however be less Vanity for me to conclude the former, than you the latter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Madam, all I shall presume to conclude, is, That if I were in Love, you'd find the means to make me soon weary on it.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Not by over-fondness, upon my word, Sir. But pray let●s stop here, for you are so much govern'd by Instinct, I know you'll grow brutish at last.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: (aside) Now am I sure she's fond of him: I'll try to make her jealous.
Well, for my part, I should be glad to find some-body would be so free with me, that I might know my Faults, and mend 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Then pray let me recommend this Gentleman to you: I have known him some time, and will be Surety for him, That upon a very limited Encouragement on your side, you shall find an extended Impudence on his.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p:
I thank you Madam, for your recommendation; But hating idleness, I'm unwilling to enter into a place where I believe
there would be nothing to do. I was fond of serving your Ladyship, because I knew you'd find me constant imployment.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: I told you he'd be rude, Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O, a little Bluntness is a sign of honesty, which makes me always ready to pardon it. So, Sir, if you have no other exceptions to my service, but the fear of being idle in't, You may venture to list your self: I shall find you work I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Upon those terms I engage, Madam, and this (with your leave) I take for earnest. Offering to kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold there, Sir, I'm none of your earnest givers. But if I'm well serv'd, I give good wages and pay punctually. Heart. and Bell. seem to continue talking familiarly.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: (Aside) I don't like this jesting between 'em— methinks the Fool begins to look as if he were in earnest— but then he must be a Fool indeed.

— Lord what a difference there is between me and her. Looking at Bel. scornfully. How I should despise such a thing if I were a man.— What a Nose she has— What a Chin— What a Neck— Then her Eyes— And the worst Kissing Lips in the Universe— No no, he can never like her that's positive— Yet I can't suffer 'em together any longer.
Mr. Heartfree, do you know that you and I must have no Quarrel for all this. I can't forbear being a little severe now and then: But Women you know may be allowed any thing.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Up to a certain age, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Which I am not yet past I hope.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: (Aside) Nor never will, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Lady Fan.
sp.p: to Lady B. Come Madam; Will your Ladyship be witness to our Reconciliation?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: You agree then at last.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: (slightingly) We forgive.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: (Aside) That was a cold ill-natur'd reply.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Then there's no Challenges sent between you?

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: Not from me I promise. (Aside to Constant) But that's more than I'll do for her, for I know she can as well be damn'd as forbear writing to me.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: That I believe. But I think we had best be going lest she should suspect something, and be maliciou.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p: With all my my heart.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ladies we are your humble Servants. I see Sir Iohn is quite engag'd, 'twould be in vain to expect him. Come Heartfree Exit.

sp.speaker: Heartfr.
sp.p:
Ladies your Servant. (to Bellinda) I hope Madam you
won't forget our Bargain; I'm to say what I please to you

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Liberty of Speech entire, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: (Aside) Very pretty truly— But how the Block head went out: Languishing at her; and not a look toward me. Well; Churchmen may talk, but Miracles are not ceas'd. For 'tis more than natural, such a Rude fellow as he, and such a little impertinent as she, should be capable of making a Woman of my sphere uneasy.
But I can bear her sight no longer— methinks she's grown ten times uglier than Cornet.
I must go home, and study revenge.
(To Lady B.) Madam your humble Servant, I must take my leave.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What going already Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: I must beg you'l excuse me this once. For really I have eighteen visits to return this afternoon so you see I'm importuned by the Women as well as the Men.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: (Aside.) And she's quits with 'em both.
(Lady Fanc. going.) Nay you sha'n't go one step out of the room.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Indeed I'll wait upon you down.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: No, sweet Lady Brute; you know I swoon at Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Pray give me leave.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: You know I won't.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Indeed I must.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Indeed you sha'n't.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Indeed I will.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Indeed you sha'n't.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Indeed I will.

sp.speaker: Lady Fanc.
sp.p: Indeed you sha'n't. Indeed Indeed Indeed you sha'n't.
sp.stage: Exit Lady Fanc. running. They follow.
sp.p: This impertinent Woman, has put me out of humour for a Fortnight.— What an agreeable moment has her foolish visit interrupted— Lord how like a Torrent Love flows into the Heart when once the sluce of desire is open'd! Good Gods what a pleasure there is in doing what we shou'd not do!
Ha! here again?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Tho' the renewing my visit may seem a little irregular,
I hope I shall obtain your pardon for it, Madam, when you know I only left the Room, lest the Lady who was here shou'd have been as malicious in her Remarks, as she's foolish in her Conduct.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: He who has discretion enough to be tender of a Womans Reputation, carries a Virtue about him may atone for a great many faults.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: If it has a Title to atone for any, it's pretentions must needs be strongest, where the Crime is Love. I therefore hope I shall be forgiven the attempt I have made upon your Heart, since my Enterrprize has been a secret to all the World but your self.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Secrecy indeed in sins of this kind, is an Argument of weight to lessen the Punishment; but nothing's a Plea, for a Pardon entire, without a sincere Repentance.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: If Sincerity in Repentance, consist in sorrow for offending: No Cloister ever enclosed, so true a Penitent as I should be. But I hope it cannot be reckon'd an offence to Love, where 'tis a duty to adore.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: 'Tis an offence, a great one, where it wou'd rob a Woman of all she ought to be ador'd for; her Virtue.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Virtue?— Virtue alas is no more like the thing that's call'd so, than 'tis like Vice it self. Virtue consists in Goodness, Honour, Gratitude, Sincerity and Pity; and not in Peevish, snarling streightlac'd Chastity. True Virtue whereso'e'er it moves, still carries an intrinsique worth about it, and is in every place, and in each Sex of equal value. So is not Continence you see: That Phantome of Honour, which men in every Age have so contemn'd, they have thrown it amongst the Women to scrable for.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: If it be a thing of so very little Value; Why do you so earnestly recommend it to your Wives and Daughters?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We recommend it to our Wives, Madam, because we wou'd keep 'em to our selves. And to our Daughters, because we wou'd dispose of 'em to others.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: 'Tis then of some Importance it seems, since you can't dispose of 'em without it.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: That importance, Madam, lies in the humour of the Country, not in the nature of the thing.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: How do you prove that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: From the Wisdom of a neighb'ring Nation in a Contrary Practice. In Monarchies things go by Whimsie, but Commonwealth's weigh all things in the Scale of Reason.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I hope we are not so very light a People to bring up fashions without some Ground.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pray what do's your Ladiship think of a powder'd Coat 〈◊〉 Dee● Mourning▪

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I think, Sir, your Sophistry has all the effect that you can reasonably expect it shou'd have: it puzzles, but don't convince

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I'm sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I'm sorry to hear you say so.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pray why?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Because if you expected more from it, you have a worse opinion of my understanding than I desire you shou'd have.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: aside. I comprehend her: She wou'd have me set a value upon her Chastity, that I may think my self the more oblig'd to her, when she makes me a present of it.

To her. I beg you will believe I did but rally, Madam, I know you judge too well of Right and Wrong, to be deceiv'd by Arguments like those. I hope you'll have so favourable an opinion of my Understanding too, to believe the thing call'd Virtue has worth enough with me, to pass for an eternal Obligation where're 'tis sacrific'd.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: It is I think so great a one, as nothing can repay.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes; the making the man you love your everlasting Debtor.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: When Debtors once have borrow'd all we have to lend, they are very apt to grow very shy of their Creditors Company.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: That, Madam, is only when they are forc'd to borrow of Usurers, and not of a Generous Friend. Let us choose our Creditors, and we are seldom so ungrateful to shun 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What think you of Sir Iohn, Sir? I was his free choice.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I think he's marri'd, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Do's Marriage then exclude men from your Rule of Constancy.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: It do's. Constancy's a Brave, free, haughty, generous Agent, that cannot buckle to the Chains of Wedlock. There's a poor sordid slavery in Marriage, that turns the slowing Tyde of Honour, and sinks us to the lowest ebb of Infamy. 'Tis a corrupted Soil; I'll Nature, Avarice, Sloath, Cowardice and Dirt, are all its product.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Have you no exceptions to this General Rule▪ as well as to to'ther?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes: I wou'd (after all) be an exception to it my self if you were free, in Power and Will to make me so.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Compliments are well plac'd, where 'tis impossible to lay hold on 'em.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
I wou'd to Heaven 'twere possible for you to lay hold on mine, that you might see it is no Compliment at all. But since you are already dispos'd on beyond Redemption, to one who ●os not know the value of the Jewel you have put into his hands: I hope you wou'd not think him greatly wrong'd, tho' it should sometimes
be look'd on by a Friend, who knows how to esteem it as he ought.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: If looking on't alone wou'd serve his turn, the wrong perhaps might not be very great.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why, what if he shou'd wear it now and then a day, so he gave good Security to bring it home again at night?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Small Security I fansie might serve for that. One might venture to take his word.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Then where's the injury to the Owner?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: 'Tis an injury to him, if he think it one. For if Happiness be seated in the Mind, Unhappiness must be so too.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Here I close with you, Madam, and draw my conclusive Argument from your own Position: If the injury lie in the fancy, there needs nothing but Secrecy to prevent the Wrong.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: going, A surer way to prevent it, is to hear no more Arguments in it's behalf.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: following her. But, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: But, Sir, 'tis my turn to be discreet now, and not suffer too long a Visit.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: catching her Hand. By Heaven you shall not stir, till you give me hopes that I shall see you again, at some more convenient Time and Place.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I give you just Hopes enough— (breaking from him) To get loose from you: And that's all I can afford you at this time.

Now by all that's Great and Good, she is a charming Woman. In what Extasie of Joy she has left me. For she gave me Hope; Did she not say she gave me Hope? Hope? Ay; what Hope?— enough to make me let her go— Why that's enough in Conscience. Or no matter how 'twas spoke; Hope was the word: It came from her, and it was said to me.

Ha, Heartfree: Thou hast done me Noble Service in pratling to the young Gentlewoman without there; come to my Arms, Thou Venerable Bawd, and let me squeeze thee (Embracing him eagerly) as a new pair of stayes does a Fat Country Girl, when she's carry'd to Court to stand for a Maid of Honour.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why what the Devil's all this Rapture for?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Rapture? There's ground for Rapture, man, there's hopes, 〈…〉, hopes, my Friend.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Hope's? of what?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why hopes that my Lady and I together, (for 'tis more than one bodies work) should make Sir Iohn a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Prithee what did she say to thee?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Say? what did she not say? she said that— says she— she said— Zoons I don't know what she said: But she look'd as if she said every thing I'd have her, and so if thou'lt go to the Tavern, I'll treat thee with any thing that Gold can buy; I'll give all my Silver amongst the Drawers, make a Bonfire before the Door, say the Plenipo's, have sign'd the Peace, and the Bank of England is grown honest. Exeunt.

div.stage: SCENE opens. Lord Rake, Sir Iohn, &c. at a Table drinking.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Huzza.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Come Boys. Charge again.— So— Confusion to all order. Here's Liberty of Conscience.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Huzza.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: I'll Sing you a Song I made this morning to this purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: 'Tis wicked I hope.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: Don't my Lord tell you he made it?

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Well then let's ha't.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: WHat a Pother of Late
Have they kept in the State
About setting our Consciences free
A Bottle has more
Dispensation in Store,
Than the King and the State can decree.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: When my Head's full of Wine,
I o'er flow with Design
And know no penal Laws that can curb me.
What e'er I devise,
Seems good in my Eyes,
And Religion ne'er dares to disturb me

lg.head: III.
lg.l: No saucy remorse
Intrudes in my Course,
Nor Impertinent notions of Evil▪
So there's Claret in store,
In Peace I've my Whore,
And in Peace I jog on to the Devil.
All Sing. So there's Claret, &c.
