Lord R. (Rep.) And in Peace I jog on to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Well, how do you like it, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O, Admirable.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: I wou'd not give a fig for a Song, that is not full of Sin and Impudence.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Then my Muse is to your taste.
But drink away; The Night steals upon us, we shall want time to be Lewd in. Hey Page, sally out, Sirrah, and see what's doing in the Camp, we'll beat up their Quarters presently.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I'll bring your Lordship an Exact account. Ex. Page.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.l: Now let the spirit of Clary go round.
Fill me a Brimmer. Here's to our forlorn-hope.
Courage Knight; Victory attends you.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: And Lawrells shall Crown me. Drink away and be damn'd

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Again Boys; to'ther Glass, and damn Morality.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p:
(drunk) Ay— damn Morality— and damn the Watch.
And let the Constable be married.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Huzza.

sp.speaker: Lady R.
sp.p: How are the Streets inhabited, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: My Lord it's Sunday night, they are full of Drunken Citizens.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Along then Boys, we shall have a feast.

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: Along Noble Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Ay— along Bully; and he that says Sir Iohn Brute, is not as Drunk and as Religious, as the Drunkenest Citizen of 'em all— is a liar, and the Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Col. Bul.
sp.p: Why that was bravely spoke, and like a free-born Englishman.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: What's that to you, Sir, whether I am an English man or a French man?

sp.speaker: Col. B.
sp.p: Zoons, you are not angry, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: Zoons I am angry, Sir,— for if I am a Free-born English man, what have you to do, even to talk of my Privileges.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Why prithee Knight don't quarrel here, leave private Animosities to be decided by day light, let the night be imployed against the publick Enemy.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: My Lord I respect you, because you are a man of Quality: But I'll make that fellow know I am within a hairs breadth as absolute by my Priveleges, as the King of France is by his prerogative. He by his prerogative takes money where it is not his due; I, by my Privelege refuse paying it, where I owe it. Liberty and Property and Old England, Huzza. Exit Sir I. reeling, all following him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Huzza.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Sure it's late, Bellinda? I begin to be sleepy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes 'tis near twelve. Will you go to Bed?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: To bed my Dear? And by that time I'm fallen into a sweet sleep, (or perhaps a sweet Dream which is better and better) Sir Iohn will come home, roaring drunk, and be over-joy'd he finds me in a Condition to be disturb'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 in need ●●t Fear him, he's in for all night 〈◊〉 The Servant's in he's gone to drink with my Lord Rake?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Nay tis not very likely indeed, such suitable Company should part presently. What Hogs Men turn, Bellinda, when they grow 〈◊〉 or Women.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And what Owles they are whilst they are fond of 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: But that we may forgive well enough, because they are so upon our Accounts.
We ought to do so indeed: But 'tis a hard matter.

For when a man is really in love he looks so unsufferably silly that tho a Woman lik'd him well enough before, she has then 〈…〉 o, to endure the sight of him. And this I take to be the reason, why Lovers are so generally ill used.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well ●own now, I'm well enough pleased to see a man look like an Ass for me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, I'm pleas'd he should look like an Ass too— That is I'm pleased with my self for making him look so.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Nay truly▪ I think it 〈◊〉 find some other way to express his Passion, 'twould be more to his advantage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes; For then a Woman might like his Passion and him too.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Yet, Bellinda, after all, A Woman's life▪ would be but a dull business, if 'twere not for Men; And Men that can look like Asses too. We shou'd never blame Fate, for the shortness of our days; our time wou'd hang wretchedly upon our hands.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why truly they do help us off with a good share on't. For were there no Men in the World, O' my Conscience I shou'd be no longer a dressing than I'm a saying my prayers; Nay tho it were Sunday: For you know that one may go to Church without Stays on.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: But don't you think Emulation might do something; for every Woman you see desires to be finer than her Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's only that the men may like her better than her Neighbour. No● if there were no men, adieu fine Petticoats, we shou'd be weary of wearing 'em.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: And adieu Plays, we shou'd be weary of seeing 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Adieu Hide-Park, the Dust wou'd Choak us.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Adieu St. Iames's, Walking wou'd Tire us.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Adieu London, the smoak would stifle us.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: And adieu going to Church, for Religion wou'd ne'er prevail with us.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Ha ha ha ha ha

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Our Confession is so very hearty, sure we merit Absolution.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Not unless we go through with't, and confess all. So prithee, for the Ease of our Consciences, let's hide nothing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why then I confess, That I love to sit in the Fore-front of a Box. For if one sits behind, there's two Acts gone perhaps, before one's found out. And when I am there, if I perceive the Men whispering and looking upon me, you must know I cannot for my Life forbear thinking they talk to my Advantage. And that sets a Thousand little tickling Vanities on Foot.—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Just my Case for all the World; but go on.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I watch with Impatience for the next Jest in the Play, that I may laugh and shew my white Teeth. If the Poet has been dull, and the Jest be long a coming, I pretend to whisper one to my Friend, and from thence fall into a little short Discourse, in which I take Occasion to shew my Face in all Humours, Brisk, Pleas'd, Serious, Melancholy, Languishing;— Not that what we say to one another causes any of these Alterations. But—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Don't trouble your self to explain: For if I'm not mistaken, you and I have had some of these necessary Dialogues before now, with the same Intention.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why I'll swear Bellinda, some People do give strange agreeable Airs to their Faces in speaking.
Tell me true!— Did you never practice in the Glass?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why, did you?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Yes Faith, many a time.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And I too, I own it. Both how to speak my self, and how to look when others speak; But my Glass and I cou'd never yet agree what Face I shou'd make, when they come blurt out, with a nasty thing in a Play: For all the Men presently look upon the Women, that's certain; so laugh we must not, though our Stays burst for't, Because that's telling Truth, and owning we understand the Jest. And to look serious is so dull, when the whole House is a laughing.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Besides, that looking serious, do's really betray our Knowledge in the Matter, as much as laughing with the Company wou'd do. For if we did not understand the thing, we shou'd naturally do like other People.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: For my part I always take that Occasion to blow my Nose.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: You must blow your Nose half off then at some Plays.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why don't some Reformer or other, beat the Poet for't?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Because he is not so sure of our private Approbation as of our publick Thanks. Well, sure there is not upon Earth, so impertinent a thing, as Womens Modesty.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes; Mens Fantasque, that obliges us to it.
If we quit our Modesty, they say we lose our Charms, and yet they know that very Modesty is Affectation, and rail at our Hypocrisie.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Thus one wou'd think, 'twere a hard Matter to please 'em, Neice. Yet our kind Mother Nature has given us something, that makes amends for all. Let our Weakness be what it will, Mankind will still be weaker, and whilst there is a World, 'tis Woman that will govern it.

But prithee one word of poor Constant before we go to Bed; if it be but to furnish Matter for Dreams; I dare swear he's talking of me now, or thinking of me at least, tho' it be in the middle of his Prayers.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So he ought I think; for you were pleas'd to make him a good round Advance to day, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why, I have e'en plagu'd him enough to satisfie any reasonable Woman: He has besieg'd me these two Years to no Purpose.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And if he besieg'd you two Years more, he'd be well enough paid, so he had the plundering of you at last.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: That may be; but I'm afraid the Town won't be able to hold out much longer; for to confess the Truth to you, Bellinda, the Garrison begins to grow mutinous.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then the sooner you capitulate, the better.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Yet methinks I wou'd fain stay a little longer, to see you fix'd too, that we might start together, and see who cou'd love longest. What think you if Heartfree shou'd have a Month's Mind to you?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why Faith I cou'd almost be in Love with him, for despising that foolish affected Lady Fancyfull, but I'm afraid he's too cold ever to warm himself by my Fire.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Then he deserves to be froze to Death. Wou'd I were a Man for your sake, my dear Rogue. Kissing her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You'd wish your self a Woman again for your own, or the Men are mistaken.
But if I cou'd make a Conquest of this Son of Bacchus, and rival his Bottle: What shou'd I do with him, he has no Fortune; I can't marry him; and sure you wou'd not have me commit Fornication.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why, if you did, Child, 'twou'd be but a good friendly part; if 'twere only to keep me in Countenance whilst I commit— You know what.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, if I can't resolve to serve you that way, I may perhaps some other, as much to your Satisfaction. But pray how shall we contrive to see these Blades again quickly?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: We must e'en have Recourse to the old way; make 'em an Appointment 'twixt jest and earnest, 'twill look like a Frolick, and that you know's a very good thing to save a Woman's Blushes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You advise well; but where shall it be?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: In Spring-Garden. But they shan't know their Women, till their Women pull off their Masques; for a Surprize is the most agreeable thing in the World: And I find my self in a very good Humour, ready to do 'em any good turn I can think on.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then pray write 'em the necessary Billet, without farther Delay.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Let's go into your Chamber then, and whilst you say your Prayers, I'll do it, Child.

div.trailer: The End of the Third ACT.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Enter Lord Rake, Sir John, &c. with Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: IS the Dog dead?

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: No, damn him, I heard him wheeze.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: How the Witch his Wife howl'd!

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: Ay, she'll alarm the Watch presently.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Appear, Knight, then; come, you have a good Cause to fight for, there's a Man murder'd.

sp.speaker: Sir. Iohn.
sp.p: Is there? Then let his Ghost be satisfied: For I'll sacrifice a Constable to it presently; and burn his Body upon his wooden Chair.

div.stage: Enter a Taylor, with a Bundle under his Arm.

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: How now? What have we got here? A Thief?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: No an't please you; I'm no Thief.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: That we'll see presently: Here, let the General examine him.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Ay, Ay; Let me examine him; and I'll lay a Hundred Pound I find him guilty, in spight of his Teeth— for he looks— like a— sneaking Rascal.
Come Sirrah, without Equivocation, or mental Reservation, tell me of what Opinion you are, and what Calling; for by them— I shall guess at your Morals.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: An't please you, I'm a Dissenting Journeyman Taylor.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Then Sirra, you love Lying by your Religion, and Theft by your Trade. And so, that your Punishment may be suitable to your Crimes,— I'll have you first gagg'd,— and then hang'd.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Pray good worthy Gentlemen, don't abuse me; indeed I'm an honest Man, and a good Workman, tho' I say it, that shou'd not say it.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: No Words, Sirrah, but attend your Fate.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Let me see what's in that Bundle.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: An't please you, it's the Doctor of the Parish's Gown.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: The Doctor's Gown!— Heark you, Knight, you won't stick at abusing the Clergy, will you?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: No, I'm drunk, and I'll abuse any thing— but my Wife▪ and her I name— with Reverence.

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: Then you shall wear this Gown, whilst you charge the Watch. That tho' the Blows fall upon you, the Scandal may light upon the Church.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: A generous Design— by all the Gods— give it me. Takes the Gown and puts it on.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: O dear Gentlemen, I shall be quite undone, if you take the Gown.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Retire, Sirrah; and since you carry off your Skin— go home, and be happy.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: [pausing] I think I had e'en as good follow the Gentleman's friendly Advice. For if I dispute any longer, who knows but the whim may take him to Case me. These Courtiers are fuller of Tricks than they are of Money; they'll sooner cut a Man's Throat, than pay his Bill.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: So, how d'ye like my Shapes now?

sp.speaker: Lord R.
sp.p: This Will do to a Miracle; he looks like a Bishop going to the Holy War. But to your Arms, Gentlemen, the Enemy appears.

sp.speaker: Watchman.
sp.p: Stand! Who goes there? Come before the Constable.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: The Constable's a Rascal— and you are the Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Watchman.
sp.p: A good civil Answer for a Parson, truly.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Methinks Sir, a Man of your Coat, might set a better Example.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'll make you know— there are Men of my Coat can set as bad Examples— as you can do, you Dog you.

div.stage: Sir John strikes the Constable. They knock him down, disarm him and seize him. Lord R. &c. run away.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: So, we have secur'd the Parson however.

sp.speaker: Sir Ioh.
sp.p: Blood and Blood— and Blood.

sp.speaker: Watchman.
sp.p: Lord have Mercy upon us: How the wicked Wretch Raves of Blood. I'll warrant he has been murdering some body to, Night.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sirrah, There's nothing got by Murder but a Halter: My Talent lies towards Drunkenness and Simony.

sp.speaker: Watchman.
sp.p: Why that now was spoke like a Man of Parts, Neighbours: It's pity he shou'd be so Disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: You Lye,— I am not Disguis'd; for I am Drunk barefac'd.

sp.speaker: Watchman.
sp.p: Look you there again,— This is a mad Parson, Mr. Constable; I'll lay a Pot of Ale upon's Head, he's a good Preacher.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Come Sir, out of Respect to your Calling, I shan't put you into the Round-house; but we must Secure you in our Drawing-Room till Morning, that you may do no Mischief. So, Come along.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: You may put me where you will, Sirrah, now you have overcome me;— But if I can't do Mischief, I'll think of Mischief— in spite of your Teeth, you Dog you.
What the Plague Ail's me?— Love? No, I thank you for that; my heart's Rock still.—
Yet 'tis Bellinda that disturbs me; that's positive.
— Well, what of all that? Must I love her for being troublesome? at that rate, I might love all the Women I meet, I gad.
But hold?— tho' I don't love her for disturbing me, yet she may disturb me, because I love her— Ay, that may be, faith.
I have dream't of her, that's certain—
Well, so I have of my Mother; therefore what's that to the purpose?
Ay, but Bellinda runs in my Mind waking—
And so do's many a damn'd thing, that I don't care a Farthing for—
Methinks tho', I would fain be talking to her, and yet I have no Business.—
Well, am I the first Man, that has had a Mind to do an Impertinent thing?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How now, Heartfree? What makes you up and Dress'd so soon? I thought none but Lovers quarrell'd with their Beds; I expected to have found you snoaring, as I us'd to do.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why, faith Friend, 'tis the Care I have of your Affairs, that makes me so thoughtful; I have been studying all Night, how to bring your Matter about with Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: With Bellinda?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: With my Lady, I mean: And faith I have mighty hopes on't. Sure you must be very well satisfy'd with her Behaviour to you Yesterday?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: So well; that nothing but a Lover's Fears, can make me doubt of Success. But what can this sudden Change proceed from?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why, you saw her Husband beat her, did you not?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: That's true: A Husband is scarce to be born upon any terms, much less when he fights with his Wife. Methinks she shou'd e'en have Cuckolded him upon the very spot, to shew that after the Battel, she was Master of the Field.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: A Council of War of Women, would infallibly have advis'd her to't. But, I confess, so agreeable a Woman as Bellinda, deserves a better usage.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Bellinda again?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: My Lady, I mean: What a-pox makes me blunder so to day? [aside] A Plague of this treacherous Tongue.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Prithee look upon me seriously, Heartfree— Now answer me directly! Is it my Lady, or Bellinda, employs your careful Thoughts thus?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: My Lady, or Bellinda?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: In Love, by this Light in Love.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: In Love?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, ne'er deny it: for thou'lt do it so awkerdly, 'twill but make the Jest sit heavier about thee. My Dear Friend, I give thee much Joy▪

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why prithee, you won't perswade me to it, will you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: That she's Mistress of your Tongue, that's plain, and I know you are so honest a Fellow, your Tongue and Heart always go together.
But how? but how the Devil? Pha, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Hey day: Why sure you don't believe it in earnest?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, I do; because I see you deny it in jest.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Nay, but look you Ned,— a— deny in jest— a— gadzooks, you know I say— a— when a Man denies a thing in jest— a—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Nay, then we shall have it: What, because a Man stumbles at a word: Did you never make a Blunder?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, for I am in Love, I own it.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.l: Then; so am I.—
Now laugh till thy Soul's glutted with Mirth, [Embracing him.]
But, dear Constant, don't tell the Town on't.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, then 'twere almost pity to laugh at thee, after so honest a Confession.
But tell us a little, Iack. By what new-invented Arms, has this mighty Stroak been given?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: E'en by that unaccountable Weapon, call'd, Ie ne sçai quoy; For every thing that can come within the Virge of Beauty, I have seen it with Indifference.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: So in few words then; the, Ie ne sçai quoy, has been too hard for the Quilted Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I gad, I think the Ie ne sçai quoy, is in the Quilted Petticoat; at least, 'tis certain, I ne'er think on't without— a— a Ie ne sçai quoy in every Part about me.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well, but have all your Remedies lost their Virtue, have you turn'd her In-side out yet?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I dare not so much as think on't.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But don't the two Years Fatigue, I have had, discourage you?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Yes: I dread what I foresee; yet cannot quit the Enterprize. Like some Soldiers; whose Courage dwells more in their Honour, than their Nature; On they go, tho' the Body trembles, at what the Soul makes it Undertake.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, if you expect your Mistress will use you, as your Profanations against her Sex deserve, you tremble Justly.
But how do you intend to proceed, Friend?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Thou know'st I'm but a Novice; be friendly and advise me.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why look you then; I'd have you— Serenade and a— write a Song— Go to Church; Look like a Fool— Be very Officious: Ogle, Write and Lead out; And who knows, but in a Year or two's time, you may be— call'd a troublesome Puppy, and sent about your Business.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: That's hard.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yet thus it oft falls out with Lovers, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Pox on me for making one of the Number.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Have a Care: Say no Saucy things: 'twill but augment your Crime, and if your Mistress hears on't, encrease your Punishment.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Prithee say something then to encourage me, you know I help'd you in your Distress.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why then to encourage you to Perseverance, that you may be thoroughly ill us'd for your Offences, I'll put you in Mind, That even the coyest Ladies of 'em all, are made up of Desires, as well as we; and tho' they do hold out a long time, they will Capitulate at last. For that thundering Engenier, Nature, do's make such havock in the Town, they must Surrender at long Run, or Perish in their own Flames.
Sir, There's a Porter without with a Letter; he desires to give it into your own Hands.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Call him in.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What Io; Is it thee?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: An't please you Sir, I was Order'd to Deliver this into your own Hands, by two well-shap'd Ladies, at the New-Exchange. I was at your Honour's Lodgings, and your Servants sent me hither.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis well, Are you to carry any Answer?

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: No, my noble Master. They gave me my Orders, and whip, they were gone, like a Maiden-head at Fifteen.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Very well; there. Gives him Money.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: God bless your Honour.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Now let's see, what honest trusty Io has brought us.

body.p: If you and your Play-fellow, can spare time from your Business and Devotions, don't fail to be at Spring-Garden about Eight in the Evening. You'll find nothing there but Women, so you need bring no other Arms than what you usually carry about you.

sp.p: So, Play-fellow: Here's something to stay your Stomach, till your Mistresses Dish is ready for you.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Some of our old Batter'd Acquaintance. I wont go, not I.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, that you can't avoid: There's honour in the Case, 'tis a Challenge, and I want a Second.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I doubt I shall be but a very useless one to you; for I'm so dishearten'd by this Wound Bellinda has given me; I don't think I shall have Courage enough to draw my Sword.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O, if that be all, come along; I'll warrant you find Sword enough for such Enemies as we have to deal withal.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Come along, Sir, I thought to have let you slip this Morning, because you were a Minister; but you are as Drunk and as Abusive as ever. We'll see what the Justice of the Peace will say to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: And you shall see what I'll say to the Justice of the Peace, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: Pray Acquaint his Worship, we have got an unruly Parson here: We are unwilling to expose him, but don't know what to do with him.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: I'll Acquaint my Master.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: You— Constable— What damn'd Justice is this?

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: One that will take Care of you, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Constable; What's the Disorder here?

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: An't Please your Worship—

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Let me speak and be damn'd: I'm a Divine, and can unfold Mysteries better than you can do.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Sadness, Sadness, a Minister so Over-taken. Pray Sir, Give the Constable leave to speak, and I'll hear you very patiently; I assure you Sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir,— You are a very Civil Magistrate. Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: An't Please your Worship then; he has attempted to beat the Watch to Night, and Swore—

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: You Lye.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Hold, pray Sir, a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir, your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, he came at us without any Provocation, call'd us Whores and Rogues, and laid us on with a great Quarter-Staff. He was in my Lord Rake's Company. They have been playing the Devil to Night.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Hem— Hem— Pray Sir— May you be Chaplain to my Lord?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir— I presume— I may if I will.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: My meaning Sir, is— Are you so?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir,— You mean very well.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: He hem— hem— Under favour, Sir, Pray Answer me directly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Under favour, Sir— Do you use to Answer directly when you are Drunk?

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Good lack, good lack: Here's nothing to be got from him. Pray Sir, may I crave your Name?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir,— My Name's— He Hycops. Hyccop, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Hyccop? Doctor Hyccop. I have known a great many Country Parsons of that Name, especially down in the Fenns. Pray where do you live, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Here— and there, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Why, what a strange Man is this? Where do you Preach, Sir? Have you any Cure?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir— I have— a very good Cure— for a Clap, at your Service.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Lord have mercy upon us.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: [Aside.] This Fellow do's Ask so many Impertinent Questions, I believe I gad, 'tis the Justice's Wife, in the Justice's Clothes.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Mr. Constable, I Vow and Protest, I don't know what to do with him.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: Truly, he has been but a troublesom Guest to us all Night.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: I think, I had e'en best let him go about his Business, for I'm unwilling to expose him.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: E'en what your Worship thinks fit.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir,— not to interrupt Mr. Constable, I have a small Favour to ask.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Sir, I open both my Ears to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir, your very humble Servant. I have a little Urgent Business calls upon me; And therefore I desire the Favour of you, to bring Matters to a Conclusion.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Sir, If I were sure that Business, were not to Commit more Disorders; I wou'd release you.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: None,— By my Priesthood.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Then, Mr. Constable, you may Discharge him.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir, your very humble Servant. If you please to Accept of a Bottle—

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I thank you kindly, Sir; but I never drink in a Morning. Good-buy to ye, Sir, good-buy to ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Good-buy t'ye, good Sir. Exit Iustice.
So— now, Mr. Constable, Shall you and I go pick up a Whore together.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: No, thank you, Sir; My Wife's enough to satisfie any reasonable Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: [Aside.] He, he, he, he, he,— the Fool is Married then. Well, you won't go?

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: Not I, truly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Then I'll go by my self; and you and your Wife may be Damn'd.
Why God-a-marcy Parson.

div.stage: Constant and Heartfree Cross the Stage. As they go off, Enter Lady Fancyfull and Madamoiselle, Mask'd and Dogging 'em.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: So: I think we are about the time appointed; Let us walk up this way.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Good: Thus far I have Dogg'd 'em without being discover'd. 'Tis infallibly some Intrigue that brings them to Spring-Garden. How my poor Heart is torn and wrackt with Fear and Jealousie. Yet let it be any thing, but that Flirt Bellinda, and I'll try to hear it. But if it prove her, All that's Woman in me shall be employ'd to destroy her. Exeunt after Constant and Heartfree.

div.stage: Re-enter Constant and Heartfree. Lady Fancyfull and Madamoiselle still following at a Distance.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I see no Females yet, that have any thing to say to us. I'm afraid we are banter'd.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I wish we were; for I'm in no Humour to make either them or my self merry.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, I'm sure you'll make them merry enough; if I tell 'em why you are dull. But prithee why so heavy and sad, before you begin to be ill us'd?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: For the same Reason, perhaps, that you are so brisk and well pleas'd; because both Pains and Pleasures are generally more considerable in Prospect, than when they come to pass.

div.stage: Enter Lady B. and Bellinda, mask'd, and poorly dress'd.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: How now, who are these? Not our Game I hope.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: If they are, we are e'en well enough serv'd, to come hunting here, when we had so much better Game in Chase elsewhere.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: So, those are their Ladies without doubt. But I'm afraid that Doily Stuff is not worn for want of better Cloaths. They are the very Shape and Size of Bellinda and her Aunt.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: So day be inteed, Matam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: We'll slip into this close Arbor, where we may hear all they say.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What, are you afraid of us, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why truly I think we may, if Appearance don't lye.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Do you always find Women what they appear to be, Sir?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: No Forsooth; but I seldom find 'em better than they appear to be.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then the Outside's best, you think?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: 'Tis the honestest.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Have a care, Heartfree; you are relapsing again.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why, does the Gentleman use to rail at Women?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: He has done formerly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I suppose he had very good Cause for't:
They did not use you so well, as you thought you deserv'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: They made themselves merry at your Expence, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Laugh'd when you Sigh'd

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Slept while you were waking.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Had your Porter beat.

sp.speaker: Lady B
sp.p: And threw your Billet doux in the Fire.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Hey day, I shall do more than rail presently.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why you won't beat us, will you?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I don't know but I may.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What the Devil's coming here? Sir Iohn in a Gown?— And drunk I'faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: What a Pox— here's Constant, Heartfree,— and two Whores I gad:— O you covetous Rogues; what, have you never a spare Punk for you Friend?— But I'll share with you.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why, what the Plague have you been doing, Knight.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Why, I have been beating the Watch, and scandalizing the Clergy.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: A very good Account, truly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: And what do you think I'll do next?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, that no Man can guess.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Why, if you'll let me sup with you, I'll treat both your Strumpets.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: [aside.] O Lord, we are undone.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: No, we can't sup together, because we have some Affairs elsewhere. But if you'll accept of these two Ladies, we'll be so complaisant to you, to resign our Right in 'em.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: [aside.] Lord, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Let me see, their Cloaths are such damn'd Cloaths, they won't pawn for the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Sir Iohn, your Servant. Rapture attend you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Adieu Ladies, make much of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why sure, you won't leave us in the Hands of a drunken Fellow to abuse us.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Who do you call a drunken Fellow, you Slut you? I'm a Man of Quality; the King has made me a Knight.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you are in good Hands, Adieu, adieu.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The Devil's Hands: Let me go, or I'll— For Heaven's sake protect us.

div.stage: She breaks from him, runs to Constant, twitching off her Mask and clapping it on again.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: I'll Devil you, you Jade you. I'll demolish your ugly Face.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Hold a little, Knight, she swoons.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: I'll swoon her.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Hey, Heartfree.

div.stage: Re-enter Heartfree. Bellinda runs to him and shews her Face.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: O Heavens! My dear Creature, stand there a little.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pull him off, Iack.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Hold, mighty Man; look you, Sir, we did but jest with you. These are Ladies of our Acquaintance, that we had a mind to frighten a little, but now you must leave us.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Oons, I won't leave you, not I.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Nay, but you must though; and therefore make no words on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Then you are a couple of damn'd uncivil Fellows. And I hope your Punks will give you sauce to your Mutton.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Oh, I shall never come to my self again, I'm so frightned.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Twas a narrow scape, indeed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Women must have Frolicks, you see, whatever they cost 'em.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: This might have prov'd a dear one tho'.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: You are the more oblig'd to us, for the Risque we run upon your Accounts.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And I hope you'll acknowledge something due to our Knight Errantry, Ladies. This is the second time we have deliver'd you.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: 'Tis true; and since we see Fate has design'd you for our Guardians, 'twill make us the more willing to trust our selves in your Hands. But you must not have the worse Opinion of us for our Innocent Frolick.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Ladies, you may command our Opinions in every thing that is to your Advantage.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I command you to be of Opinion, That Women are sometimes better than they appear to be.

div.stage: Lady Brute and Constant talk apart.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Madam, you have made a Convert of me in every thing. I'm grown a Fool: I cou'd be fond of a Woman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir, in the Name of the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Which Sex nothing but your self, cou'd ever have aton'd for.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Now has my Vanity a devilish Itch, to know in what my Merit consists.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: In your Humility, Madam, that keeps you ignorant it consists at all.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: One other Compliment with that serious Face, and I hate you for ever after.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Some Women love to be abus'd: Is that it you wou'd be at?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, not that neither: But I'd have Men talk plainly what's fit for Women to hear; without putting 'em either to a real, or an affected Blush.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why then, in as plain Terms as I can find to express my self: I cou'd love you even to— Matrimony it self a-most I-gad.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Just as Sir Iohn did her Ladyship there.

What think you? Don't you believe one Month's time might bring you down to the same Indifference, only clad in a little better Manners, perhaps. Well, you Men are unaccountable things, mad till you have your Mistresses; and then stark mad till you are rid of 'em again. Tell me, honestly, is not your Patience put to a much severer Tryal after Possession, than before?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: With a great many, I must confess, it is, to our eternal Scandal; but I— dear Creature, do but try me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: That's the surest way indeed, to know, but not the safest.
To Lady B. Madam, are not you for taking a turn in the Great Walk: It's almost dark, no body will know us.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Really I find my self something idle, Bellinda, besides, I dote upon this little odd private Corner. But don't let my lazy Fancy confine you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: [aside.] So, she wou'd be left alone with me, that's well.

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: Well, we'll take one turn, and come to you again.
To Heart. Come, Sir, shall we go pry into the secrets of the Garden. Who knows what Discoveries we may make.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Madam, I'm at your Service.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: to Heart. [aside.] Don't make too much haste back; for, d'ye hear— I may be busie.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Sure you think me scandalously free, Mr. Constant. I'm afraid I shall lose your good Opinion of me.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: My good Opinion, Madam, is like your Cruelty, never to be remov'd.

sp.speaker: Lady B
sp.p: But if I shou'd remove my Cruelty, then there's an end of your good Opinion.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: There is not so strict an Alliance between 'em neither. 'Tis certain I shou'd love you then better (if that be possible) than I do now; and where I love, I always esteem.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.l: Indeed, I doubt you much:
Why suppose you had a Wife, and she shou'd entertain a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: If I gave her just Cause, how cou'd I justly condemn her?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ah; but you'd differ widely about just Causes.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But blows can bear no Dispute.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Nor Ill Manners much, truly.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Then no Woman upon Earth, has so just a Cause as you have.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O, but a faithful Wife, is a beautiful Character.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: To a deserving Husband, I confess it is.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: But can his Faults Release my Duty?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: In Equity without doubt. And where Laws dispense with Equity; Equity should dispense with Laws.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Pray let's leave this Dispute; for you Men have as much Witchcraft in your Arguments, as Women have in their Eyes.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But whil'st you Attack me with your Charms, 'tis but reasonable I Assault you with mine.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The Case is not the same. What Mischief we do, we can't help, and therefore are to be forgiven.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Beauty soon obtains Pardon, for the Pain that it gives, when it applies the Balm of Compassion to the Wound; But a fine Face, and a hard Heart, is almost as bad as an ugly Face and a soft one: both very troublesom to many a Poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Yes, and to many a Poor Gentlewoman too, I can assure you. But pray which of 'em is it, that most afflicts you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Your Glass and Conscience will inform you, Madam. But for Heaven's sake (for now I must be serious) if Pity or if Gratitude can move you, Taking her hand. If Constancy and Truth have Power to tempt you; If Love, if Adoration can affect you, give me at least some hopes, that time may do, what you perhaps mean never to perform; 'Twill ease my Sufferings, tho' not quench my Flame.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Your Sufferings eas'd, your Flame wou'd soon abate; And that I wou'd preserve, not quench it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Wou'd you preserve it, nourish it with favours; for that's the Food, it naturally requires.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Yet on that Natural Food, 'twou'd Surfeit soon, shou'd I resolve to grant all that you wou'd ask.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
And in refusing all, you starve it. Forgive me therefore, since my Hunger rages, if I at last grow Wild, and in my frenzy force at least, This from you. Kissing her hand.
Or if you'd have my Flame, soar higher still, then grant me this, and this, and this, and Thousands more; [Kissing first her hand, then her neck. Aside.] for now's the time, She melts into Compassion.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: [Aside.] Poor Coward Vertue, how it shuns the Battle. O heavens! let me go.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Ay, go, ay: Where shall we go, my Charming Angel,— into this private Arbour.— Nay, let's lose no time— Moments are precious.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: And Lovers wild. Pray let us stop here; at least for this time.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible: He that has Power over you, can have none over himself. As he is forcing her into the Arbour, Lady Fancyful and Madamoiselle bolt out upon them, and Run over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ah; I'm lost.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Fe, fe, fe, fe, fe.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Fe, fe, fe, fe, fe.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Death and Furies, who are these?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Oh heavens, I'm out of my Wits; if they knew me, I'm Ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Don't be frightned; Ten thousand to One they are Strangers to you.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Whatever they are, I won't stay here a moment longer.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Whither will you go?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Home, as if the Devil were in me. Lord where's this Bellinda now?
O! it's well you are come: I'm so frightned my Hair stands an end.
Let's be gone for Heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Lord, What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: The Devil's the Matter, we are discover'd. Here's a Couple of Women have done the most impertinent thing. Away, Away, Away, Away, Away.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Well Madamoiselle, 'tis a Prodigious thing, how Women can suffer filthy Fellows, to grow so familiar with 'em.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Ah Matam, il n'y a rien desi Naturel.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Fe, fe, fe. But oh my Heart; O Jealousie, O Torture, I'm upon the rack. What shall I do, my Lover's lost, I ne'er shall see him. Mine.

Pausing— But I may be reveng'd; and that's the same thing. Ah sweet Revenge. Thou welcome thought, thou healing Balsam, to my wounded Soul. Be but propitious on this one Occasion, I'll place my Heaven in thee, for all my Life to come.

lg.l: To Woman how indulgent Nature's kind.
No Blast of Fortune long disturbs her Mind.
Compliance to her Fate supports her still,
If Love won't make her Happy— Mischief will.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: WEll, Madamoiselle; Did you Dogg the filthy things?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: O que Ouy Matam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: And where are they?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Au Logis.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: What? Men and All?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Tous ensemble.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: O Confidence! What, carry their Fellows to their own House?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: C'est que le Mari n'y est pas.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: No, so I believe, truly. But he shall be there, and quickly too, if I can find him out.

Well, 'tis a Prodigious thing, to see when Men and Women get together, how they fortifie one another in their Impudence. But if that Drunken Fool, her Husband, be to be found in e'er a Tavern in Town, I'll send him amongst 'em. I'll spoil their Sport.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: En Verite Matam, ce seroit domage.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: 'Tis in Vain to Oppose it, Madamoiselle; therefore never go about it. For I am the steadiest Creature in the World— when I have determin'd to do Mischief. So, Come along.

div.stage: Enter Constant, Heartfree, Lady Brute, Bellinda, and Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: But are you sure you don't Mistake, Lovewell?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, I saw 'em all go into the Tavern together, and my Master was so drunk he cou'd scarce stand.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Then, Gentlemen, I believe we may Venture to let you Stay and Play at Cards with us an Hour or two; for they'll scarce part till Morning.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I think 'tis pity they shou'd ever part.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: The Company that's here, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Then, Sir, the Company that's here, must remember to part it self, in time.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Madam, we dont intend to forfeit your future Favours, by an indiscreet Usage of this. The moment you give us the Signal, we sha'n't fail to make our Retreat.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Upon those Conditions then, Let us sit down to Cards. Enter Lovewell. O Lord, Madam, here's my Master just staggering in upon you; He has been Quarrelsom yonder, and they have kick'd him out of the Company.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Into the Closet, Gentlemen, for Heaven's sake; I'll wheedle him to Bed, if possible.

div.stage: Const. and Heart. run into the Closet.
Enter Sir John, all Dirt and Bloody.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ah— ah— he's all over Blood.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: What the Plague, do's the Woman— Squall for? Did you never see a Man in Pickle before?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Lord, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: I have been at— Cuffs.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I fear that is not all. I hope you are not wounded.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sound as a Roche, Wife.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I'm mighty glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Sir I.
sp.p: You know— I think you Lye.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I know you do me wrong to think so, then. For Heaven's my Witness, I had rather see my own Blood trickle down, than yours.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Then will I be Crucify'd.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard Fate, I shou'd not be believ'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: 'Tis a damn'd Atheistical Age, Wife.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I am sure I have given you a Thousand tender Proofs, how great my Care is of you.
Nay, spite of all your Cruel Thoughts, I'll still persist, and at this moment, if I can, perswade you to lie down, and Sleep a little.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Why,— do you think I am drunk— you Slut, you?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Heaven forbid, I shou'd: But I'm afraid you are Feaverish. Pray let me feel your Pulse.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Stand off and be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why, I see your Distemper in your very Eyes. You are all on fire. Pray go to Bed; Let me intreat you.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: — Come kiss me, then.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: [Kissing him.] There: Now go [Aside.] He stinks like Poison.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.l: I see it go's damnably against your Stomach—
And therefore— Kiss me again.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Nay, now you fool me.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Do't, I say.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.l: [Aside.] Ah Lord have mercy upon me.
Well; There; Now will you go?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Now Wife, you shall see my Gratitude. You give me two Kisses, I'll give you— two Hundred. Kisses and tumbles her.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.l: O Lord: Pray, Sir Iohn, be quiet.
Heavens, what a Pickle am I in.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: [Aside.] If I were in her Pickle, I'd call my Gallant out of the ●oset, and he shou'd Cudgel him soundly.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: So; Now, you being as dirty and as nasty as my self, We may go Pig together. But first, I must have a Cup of your Cold Tea, Wife. Going to the Closet.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O, I'm ruin'd.
〈…〉 there, my Dear.
〈◊〉 I'll warrant you, I'll find some, my Dear.
〈…〉 Open the Door, the Lock's spoil'd. I have been 〈…〉 the Key this half hour to no purpose. I'll send for 〈…〉 Morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: There's ne'er a Smith in Europe can Open a Door with more Expedition than I can do.— As for Example,— Pou. He bursts Open the Door with his foot.
— How now?—
What the Devil have we got here?—
Constant— Heartfree— And two Whores again, I gad.—— This is the worst Cold Tea— that ever I met with in my Life.—

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: [aside.] O Lord, what will become of us?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Gentlemen— I am your very humble Servant— I give you many Thanks— I see you take Care of my Family— I shall do all I can to return the Obligation.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sir, how odly soever this Business may appear to you, you wou'd have no Cause to be uneasie, if you knew the Truth of all things; your Lady is the most virtuous Woman in the World, and nothing has past, but an Innocent Frolick.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Nothing else, upon my Honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: You are both very Civil Gentlemen— And my Wife, there, is a very Civil Gentlewoman; therefore I don't doubt but many Civil things have past between you. Your very humble Servant.

sp.speaker: L. B.
sp.p: [Aside to Const.] Pray be gone; He's so drunk he can't hurt us to Night, and to Morrow Morning you shall hear from us.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I'll Obey you, Madam.
Sir, when you are Cool, you'll understand Reason better. So then I shall take the Pains to Inform you.
If not— I wear a Sword, Sir, and so good-b'uy to you.
Come along, Heartfree.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: — Wear a Sword, Sir:— And what of all that, Sir?— He comes to my House; Eats my Meat; Lies with my Wife; Dishonours my Family; Gets a Bastard to Inherit my Estate.— And when I ask a Civil Account of all this— Sir, says, he, I wear a Sword.— Wear a Sword, Sir? Yes Sir, says he; I wear a Sword— It may be a good Answer at Cross-Purposes; But 'tis a Damn'd One to a Man in my Whimsical Circumstance— Sir, says he, I wear a Sword.
To Lady B. And what do you wear now? ha? tell me.

p.stage: Sitting down in a great Chair.

sp.p: What? you are Modest and cant?—
Why then I'll tell you, you Slut you.
You wear— an Impudent Lewd Face.—
A Damn'd Designing Heart— And a Tail— and a Tail full of— He falls fast asleep, snoaring.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: So; Thanks to Kind Heaven, he's fast for some Hours.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis well he is so, that we may have time to lay our Story handsomly; for we must Lie like the Devil to bring our selves off.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What shall we say, Bellinda?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: [Musing.]— I'll tell you: It must all light upon Heartfree and I. We'll say he has Courted me some time, but for Reasons unknown to us, has ever been very earnest the thing might be kept from Sir Iohn. That therefore hearing him upon the Stairs, he run into the Closet, tho' against our Will, and Constant with him, to prevent Jealousie. And to give this a good Impudent face of Truth (that I may deliver you from the Trouble you are in:) I'll e'en (if he pleases) Marry him.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I'm beholding to you, Cousin; but that wou'd be carrying the Jest a little too far for your Own sake: You know he's a younger Brother, and has Nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis true; But I like him, and have Fortune enough to keep above Extremity: I can't say, I wou'd live with him in a Cell upon Love and Bread and Butter. But I had rather have the Man I love, and a Middle State of Life, Than that Gentleman in the Chair there, and twice your Ladiship's Splendour.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: In truth, Niece, you are in the Right on't: for I am very Uneasie with my Ambition. But perhaps, had I married as you'll do, I might have been as Ill us'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Some Risque, I do confess, there always is; But if a Man has the least spark, either of Honour or good Nature, he can never use a Woman Ill, that loves him and makes his Fortune both. Yet I must own to you, some little Struggling I still have, with this teazing Ambition of ours. For Pride, you know, is as Natural to a Woman, as 'tis to a Saint. I can't help being fond of this Rogue; and yet it go's to my Heart to think I must never Whisk to Hide-Park, with above a Pair of Horses; Have no Coronet upon my Coach, nor a Page to carry up my Train. But above all— that business of Place— Well; Taking Place, is a Noble Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Especially after a Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Or of a Rival. But pray say no more on't, for fear I change my Mind. For o' my Conscience, were't not for your Affair in the ballance, I shou'd go near to pick up some Odious Man of Quality yet, and only take poor Heartfree for a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Then him you must have, however things go?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Why we may pretend what we will; but 'tis a hard matter to Live without the Man we Love.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Especially when we are Married to the Man we hate. Pray tell me? Do the Men of the Town ever believe us Virtuous, when they see us do so?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: O, no: Nor indeed hardly, let us do what we will. They most of 'em think, there is no such thing as Virtue consider'd in the strictest notions of it: And therefore when you hear 'em say, Such a one is a Woman of Reputation, They only mean she's a Woman of Discretion. For they consider, we have no more Religion than they have, nor so much Morality; and between you and I, Bellinda, I'm afraid the want of Inclination seldom protects any of us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But what think you of the fear of being found out.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I think that never kept any Woman virtuous long. We are not such Cowards neither. No: Let us once pass Fifteen, and we have too good an Opinion of our own Cunning, to believe the World can penetrate, into what we wou'd keep a Secret. And so in short, We cannot reasonably blame the Men for judging of us by themselves.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But sure we are not so Wicked as they are, after all.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: We are as Wicked, Child, but our Vice lies another way: Men have more Courage than we, so they commit more Bold, Impudent Sins. They Quarrel, Fight, Swear, Drink, Blaspheme, and the like. Whereas we, being Cowards, only Backbite, tell Lyes, Cheat at Cards and so forth. But 'tis late. Let's end our Discourse for to Night, and out of an excess of Charity, take a small Care, of that nasty drunken thing there— Do but look at him, Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ah— 'tis a Savoury Dish.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: As savoury as 'tis, I'm cloy'd with't. Prithee Call the Butler to take away.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Call the Butler?— Call the Scavenger.
To a Servant within. Who's there? Call Rasor! Let him take away his Master, Scower him clean with a little Soap and Sand, and so put him to Bed.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Come Bellinda, I'll e'en lie with you to Night; and in the Morning we'll send for our Gentlemen to set this Matter even:

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Withal my Heart.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Good Night, my Dear. Making a low Curtsy.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

My Lady there's a Wag— My Master there's a Cuckold. Marriage is a slippery thing— Women have deprav'd Appetites:— My Lady's a Wag, I have heard all: I have seen all: I understand all, and I'll tell all; for my little French-woman loves News dearly. This Story'll gain her Heart or nothing will.

To his Master. Come, Sir, Your Head's too full of Fumes at present, to make Room for your Jealousie; but I reckon we shall have Rare work with you, when your Pate's empty. Come; to your Kennel, you Cuckoldly drunken Sot you. Carries him out upon his Back.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: But, why did not you tell me before, Madamoiselle, that Rasor and you were fond?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: De Modesty hinder me, Matam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Why truly Modesty do's often hinder us from doing things we have an Extravagant Mind to. But do's he love you well enough yet, to do any thing you bid him? Do you think to Oblige you he wou'd speak Scandal?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Matam, to Oblige your Ladiship, he shall speak Blasphemy.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Why then, Madamoiselle, I'll tell you what you shall do. You shall engage him to tell his Master, all that past at Spring-Garden. I have a Mind he shou'd know what a Wife and a Neice he has got.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Il le fera, Matam.

div.stage: Enter a Footman, who speaks to Madamoiselle apart.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Madamoiselle; Yonder's Mr. Rasor desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Tell him, I come presently. Exit Footman. Rasor be dare, Matam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: That's Fortunate: Well, I'll leave you together. And if you find him stubborn, Madamoiselle,— heark you— don't refuse him a few little reasonable Liberties, to put him into humour.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Laisez moy faire. Exit Lady Fancyfull.

div.stage: Rasor peeps in; and seeing Lady Fancyfull gone, runs to Madamoiselle, takes her about the Neck and kisses her.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: How now, Confidence.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: How now, Modesty.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Who make you so familiar, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: My Impudence, Hussy.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Stand off, Rogue-face.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Ah— Madamoiselle— great News at our House.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Wy wat be de matter?

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: The Matter?— why, Uptails All's the Matter.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Tu te mocque de moy.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.l: Now do you long to know the particulars:
The time when: The place where: The manner how;
But I won't tell you a Word more.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Nay, den dou Kill me, Rasor.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Come, Kiss me, then. Clapping his hands behind him.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Nay, pridee tell me.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Good b'wy to ye. Going.

sp.speaker: Mademois.
sp.p: Hold, hold: I will Kiss dee. Kissing him.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: So: that's Civil: Why now, my pretty Pall; My Goldfinch; My little Waterwagtail— you must know that— Come, Kiss me again.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: I won't Kiss dee no more.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Good b'wy to ye.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Doucement: Dare: es tu content? Kissing him.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: So: Now I'll tell thee all. Why the News is, That Cuckoldom in Folio, is newly Printed; and Matrimony in Quarto, is just going into the Press. Will you Buy any Books, Madamoiselle?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Tu Parle comme un Librair, de Devil no Understand dee.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Why then, that I may make my self intelligible to a Waiting-woman, I'll speak like a Vallet de Chamber. My Lady has Cuckolded my Master.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Bon.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Which we take very ill from her hands, I can tell her that. We can't yet prove Matter of Fact upon her.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: N'importe.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: But we can prove, that Matter of Fact had like to have been upon her.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Ouy da.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: For we have such bloody Circumstances.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Sans Doute.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: That any Man of Parts, may draw tickling Conclusions from 'em.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Fort bien.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: We have found a couple of tight well-built Gentlemen, stuft into her Ladiships Closet.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Le Diable

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: And I, in my particular Person, have discover'd a most Damnable Plot, how to perswade my poor Master, that all this Hide and Seek, this Will in the Wisp, has no other meaning than a Christian Marriage for sweet Mrs. Bellinda.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Une Marriage?— Ah les Droless.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Don't you interrupt me, Hussy; 'tis Agreed, I say. And my Innocent Lady, to Riggle her self out at the Back-door of the Business, turns Marriage-Bawd to her Neice, and resolves to deliver up her fair Body, to be tumbled and mumbled, by that young Liquorish Whipster, Heartfree. Now are you satisfy'd?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Right Woman; Always gaping for more.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Dis be all den, dat dou know?

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: All? Ay, and a great deal too, I think.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.l: Dou be fool, dou know noting.
Ecoute mon pauvre Rasor.
Dou see des two Eyes?— Des two Eyes have see de Devil.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: The Woman's Mad.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: In Spring-Garden, dat Rogue Constant, meet dy Lady.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Bon.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: — I'll tell dee no more.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Nay, prithee, my Swan.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Come, Kiss me den▪ Clapping her hands behind her, as he had done before.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: I won't Kiss you, not I.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Hold:— Now proceed. Gives her a hearty Kiss.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: A ça— I hide my self in one Cunning place, where I hear all, and see all. First dy drunken Master come mal a propos; But de Sot no know his own dear Wife, so he leave her to her Sport—
Den de game begin.
De Lover say soft ting. As she speaks, Rasor still acts the Man, and she the Woman.
De Lady look upon de Ground
He take her by de Hand.
She turn her Head, one oder way.
Den he squeez very hard.
Den she pull— very softly.
Den he take her in his Arm.
Den she give him, Leetel pat.
Den he Kiss her Tettons.
Den she say— Pish, nay see.
Den he tremble,
Den she— Sigh.
Den he pull her into de Arbour,
Den she pinch him

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Ay, but not so hard, you Baggage you.

sp.speaker: Mademois.
sp.p: Den he grow Bold.
She grow Weak.
He tro her down
Il tombe dessu,
Le Diable assist, Rasor struggles with her, as if he wou'd throw her down.
Il emport tout:
Stand off, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: You have set me a fire, you Jade you.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Den go to de River and quench dy self.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: What an unnatural Harlot 'tis.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Rasor. Looking languishingly on him.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Madamoiselle.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Dou no love me.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Not love thee!— More than a French-man do's Soupe.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Den dou will refuse noting dat I bid dee?

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Don't bid me be damn'd then:

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: No, only tell dy Master, all I have tell dee of dy Laty.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Why you little malicious Strumpet, you; shou'd you like to be serv'd so?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Dou dispute den?— Adieu.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Hold— But why wilt thou make me be such a Rogue, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Voilà un Vrai Anglois: il est Amoureux, et cependant il veut raisoner. Vat' en au Diable.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Hold once more: In hopes thou'lt give me up thy Body, I resign thee up my Soul.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Bon: eccute done:— if dou fail me— I never see dee more— She takes him about the Neck, and gives him a smacking Kiss.
if dou obey me—
Ie m'abandonne à toy.
Not be a Rogue?— Amor Vineit omnia. Exit Rasor.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Marry, say ye? Will the two things marry?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: On le va faire, Matam.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Look you, Madamo selle, in short, I can't bear it—— No; I find I can't— If once I see 'em a-bed together, I shall have ten thousand Thoughts in my Head will make me run distracted. Therefore run and call Rasor back immediately, for something must be done to stop this Impertinent Wedding. If I can but deferr it four and twenty Hours, I'll make such work about Town, with that little pert Sluts Reputation. He shall as soon marry a Witch.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: [aside.] La Voilà bien intentionée. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But what dost think will come of this Business?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: 'Tis easier to think what will not come on't.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: A Challenge. I know the Knight too well for that. His dear Body will always prevail upon his noble Soul to be quiet.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But tho' he dare not challenge me, perhaps he may venture to challenge his Wife.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Not if you whisper him in the Ear, you won't have him do't, and there's no other way left that I see. For as drunk as he was, he'll remember you and I were where we shou'd not be; and I don't think him quite Blockhead enough yet, to be perswaded we were got into his Wife's Closet, only to peep in her Prayer-book.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, Here's a Letter, a Porter brought it.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: O ho, here's Instructions for us.

body.p:
The Accident that has happen'd has touch'd our Invention to the quick. We wou'd fain come off, without your help; but find that's impossible. In a word, the whole Business must be thrown upon a Matrimonial Intrigue, between your Friend
and mine. But if the Parties are not fond enough, to go quite through with the Matter; 'tis sufficient for our turn, they own the Design. We'll find Pretences enough, to break the Match. Adieu.

sp.p: — Well, Woman for Invention: How long wou'd my Blockhead have been a producing this.
— Hey, Heartfree; what, musing Man? Prithee be chearful. What say'st thou, Friend, to this Matrimonial Remedy?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why I say, it's worse than the Disease.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Here's a Fellow for you: There's Beauty and Money on her Side, and Love up to the Ears on his; and yet—

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And yet, I think, I may reasonably be allow'd to boggle at marrying the Neice, in the very Moment that you are a debauching the Aunt.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why truly, there may be something in that. But have not you a good Opinion enough of your own Parts, to believe you cou'd keep a Wife to your self?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I shou'd have, if I had a good Opinion enough of hers, to believe she cou'd do as much by me. For to do 'em Right, after all, the Wife seldom rambles, till the Husband shews her the way.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis true; a Man of real Worth, scarce ever is a Cuckold, but by his own Fault▪ Women are not naturally lewd, there must be something to urge 'em to it. They'll cuckold a Churle, out of Revenge; A Fool, because they despise him; a Beast because they loath him. But when they make bold with a Man they once had a well grounded Value for, 'tis because they first see themselves neglected by him.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Nay, were I well assur'd, that I shou'd never grow Sir Iohn. I ne'er shou'd fear Bellinda ●d play my Lady. But our Weakness, thou know'st, my Friend, consists in that very Change, we so impudently throw upon (indeed) a steadier and more generous Sex.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why Faith we are a little Impudent in that Matter that's the Truth on't. But this is wonderful, to see you grown so warm an Advocate for those (but t'other Day) you took so much pains to abuse.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: All Revolutions run into Extreams, the Bigot makes the boldest Atheist; and the coyest Saint, the most extravagant Strumpet. But Prithee advise me in this good and Evil; this Life and Death, this Blessing and Cursing, that is set before me. Shall I marry— or die a Maid?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p:
Why Faith, Heartfree, Matrimony is like an Army going to engage. Love's the forlorn Hope, which is soon cut off; the Marriage-Knot is the main Body, which may stand Buff a long long time; and
Repentance is the Rear-Guard, which rarely gives ground, as long as the main Battle has a Being.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Conclusion then; you advise me to whore on, as you do.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: That's not concluded yet. For tho' Marriage be a Lottery in which there are a wondrous many Blanks; yet there is one inestimable Lot, in which the only Heaven on Earth is written. Wou'd your kind Fate but guide your Hand to that, though I were wrapt in all that Luxury it self cou'd cloath me with, I still shou'd envy you.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And justly too: For to be capable of loving one, doubtless is better than to possess a Thousand. But how far that Capacity's in me, alas I know not.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But you wou'd know?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I wou'd so.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Matrimony will inform you.
Come, one Flight of Resolution carries you to the Land of Experience; where, in a very moderate time, you'll know the Capacity of your Soul, and your Body both, or I'm mistaken. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well, Madam, what Answer have you from 'em?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: That they'll be here this Moment. I fansie 'twill end in a Wedding. I'm sure he's a Fool if it don't. Ten Thousand Pound, and such a Lass as you are, is no contemptible Offer to a younger Brother. But are not you under strange Agitations? Prithee how do's your Pulse beat?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: High and low, I have much ado to be Valiant, feel very strange to go to Bed to a Man?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Um— it do's feel a little odd at first, but it will soon grow easy to you.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Good Morrow Gentlemen: How have you slept after your Adventure?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Some careful Thoughts, Ladies, on your Accounts have kept us waking.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And some careful Thoughts on your own, I believe, have hindred you from sleeping. Pray how do's this Matrimonial Project relish with you.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Why Faith e'en as storming Towns does with Soldiers, where the Hopes of delicious Plunder banishes the Fear of being knock'd on the Head.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Is it then possible after all, That you dare think of downright lawful Wedlock?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Madam, you have made me so Fool-hardy, I dare do any thing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then Sir, I challenge you; and Matrimony's the Spot where I expect you.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: 'Tis enough; I'll not fail.
[Aside.] So, Now I am in for Hobs's Voyage; a great Leap in the Dark.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, this Matter being concluded then, have you got your Lessons ready? For Sir Iohn is grown such an Atheist of late, he'll believe nothing upon easie Terms.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We'll find ways to extend his Faith, Madam. But pray how do you find him this Morning?

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Most lamentably morose, chewing the Cud after last Night's Discovery; of which however he had but a confus'd Notion e'en now. But I'm afraid his Vallet de Chamber has told him all, for they are very busie together at this Moment. When I told him of Bellinda's Marriage, I had no other Answer but a Grunt: From which, you may draw what Conclusions you think fit.
But to your Notes, Gentlemen, He's here.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Good Morrow, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Good Morrow, Sir Iohn. I'm very sorry my Indiscretion shou'd cause so much Disorder in your Family.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Disorders generally come from Indiscretions, Sir, 'tis no strange thing at all.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: I hope, my Dear, you are satisfied there was no wrong intended you.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: None, my Dove.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: If not, I hope my Consent to marry Mr. Heartfree will convince you. For as little as I know of Amours, Sir, I can assure you, one Intrigue is enough to bring four People together, without further mischief.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: And I know too, that Intrigues tends to Procreation of more kinds than one. One Intrigue will beget another as soon as beget a Son or a Daughter.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am very sorry, Sir, to see you still seem unsatisfy'd with a Lady, whose more than common Vertue, I am sure, were she my Wife, shou'd meet a better Usage.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir, If her Conduct has put a trick upon her Vertue, her Vertue's the Bubble, but her Husband's the Loser.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sir, You have receiv'd a sufficient Answer already, to justifie both her Conduct and mine. You'll pardon me for medling in your Family Affairs; but I perceive I am the Man you are jealous of, and therefore it concerns me.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Wou'd it did not concern me, and then I shou'd not care who it concern'd.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Well, Sir, if Truth and Reason won't content you; I know but one way more, which, if you think fit, you may take.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you are very hasty: If I had been found at Prayers in your Wife's Closet, I shou'd have allow'd you twice as much time to come to your self in.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, if Time be all you want. We have no Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: I told you how the Sword wou'd work Sir John muzes. upon him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Let him muze; however, I'll lay Fifty Pound our Foreman brings us in, Not Guilty.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: [Aside.] 'Tis well— 'tis very well— In spight of that young Jade's Matrimonial Intrigue, I am a downright stinking Cuckold— Here they are— Boo— Putting his Hand to his Forehead. Methinks I could Butt with a Bull.

What the plague did I marry her for? I knew she did not like me; if she had, she wou'd have lain with me; for I wou'd have done so, because I lik'd her: But that's past, and I have her. And now, what shall I do with her— If I put my Horns in my Pocket, she'll grow Insolent.— If I don't; that Goat there, that Stallion, is ready to whip me through the Guts.— The Debate then is reduc'd to this; Shall I die a Heroe? or live a Rascal?— Why, Wiser Men than I, have long since concluded, that a living Dog is better than a dead Lion.—

[To Const. and Heart.] Gentlemen, now my Wine and my Passion are governable, I must own, I have never observ'd any thing in my Wife's Course of Life, to back me in my Jealousie of her: but Jealousie's a mark of Love; so she need not trouble her head about it, as long as I ●ake no more words on't.

div.stage: Lady Fancyf. enters Disguis'd, and Addresses to Bellinda apart.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: I am glad to see your Reason rule at last. Give me your Hand: I hope you'll look upon me as you are wont.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Your humble Servant. [Aside,] A wheedling Son of a Whore.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And that I may be sure you are Friends with me too, pray give me your Consent to wed your Niece.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Sir, you have it with all my Heart: Damn me if you han't. [Aside.] 'Tis time to get rid of her; A young Pert Pimp; She'll make an incomparable Bawd in a little time.

div.stage: Enter a Servant, who gives Heartfree a Letter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Heartfree your Husband, say you? 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Wou'd to kind Heaven it were: but 'tis too true; and in the World there lives not such a Wretch. I'm young; and either I have been flatter'd by my Friends, as well as Glass, or Nature has been kind and generous to me. I had a Fortune too, was greater far than he could ever hope for. But with my Heart, I am robb'd of all the rest. I'm Slighted and I'm Beggar'd both at once. I have scarce a bare Subsistence from the Villain, yet dare complain to none; for he has sworn, if e'er 'tis known I am his Wife, he'll murder me. Weeping.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: The Traytor.

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: I accidentally was told he Courted you; Charity soon prevail'd upon me to prevent your Misery: And as you see, I'm still so generous even to him, as not to suffer he should do a thing, for which the Law might take away his Life. Weeping.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Poor Creature; how I pity her! They continue talking aside.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: [Aside,] Death and Damnation!— Let me read it again. [Reads.]

body.p: Though I have a particular Reason, not to let you know who I am till I see you; yet you'll easily believe 'tis a faithful Friend that gives you this Advice.— I have lain with Bellinda. (Good.)— I have a Child by her, (Better and Better.) which is now at Nurse; (Heav'n be prais'd.) and I think the Foundation laid for another: (Ha!— Old Trupenny!)— No Rack could have tortur'd this Story from me; but Friendship has done it. I heard of your design to Marry her, and cou'd not see you Abus'd. Make use of my Advice, but keep my Secret till I ask you for't again. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Come, Madam; Shall we send for the Parson? I doubt here's no business for the Lawyer: Younger Brothers have nothing to settle but their Hearts, and that I believe my Friend here has already done, very faithfully.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: [scornfully.] Are you sure, Sir, there are no old Mortgages upon it.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: [coldly.] If you think there are, Madam, it mayn't be amiss to deferr the Marriage till you are sure they are paid off.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: [Aside.] How the Gall'd Horse Kicks!
[To Heart.] We'll deferr it as long as you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: The more Time we take to consider on't, Madam, the less apt we shall be to commit Oversights; Therefore, if you please, we'll put it off, for just Nine Months.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Guilty Consciences make Men Cowards: I don't wonder you want Time to Resolve.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And they make Women Desperate: I don't wonder you were so quickly Determin'd.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What does the Fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: What do's the Lady mean?

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Zoons, what do you both mean?

div.stage: Heart. and Bel. walk chasing about.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: [Aside.] Here is so much Sport going to be spoil'd, it makes me ready to weep again. A Pox o' this Impertinent Lady Fancyfull, and her Plots, and her French-woman too. She's a Whimsical, Ill-natur'd Bitch, and when I have got my Bones broke in her Service, 'tis Ten to One but my Recompence is a Clap; I hear 'em tittering without still. I Cod I'll e'en go lug 'em both in by the Ears, and Discover the Plot, to secure my Pardon. Exit. Ras.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Prithee explain, Heartfree.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: A fair Deliverance; thank my Stars and my Friend.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis well it went no farther. A Base Fellow.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What can be the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: What's his meaning, I don't know. But mine is; That if I had Married him— I had had no Husband.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: And what's her meaning, I don't know. But mine is; That if I had Married her— I had had Wife enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Your People of Wit, have got such Cramp ways of expressing themselves, they seldom comprehend one another. Pox take you both, will you speak that you may be Understood.

div.stage: Enter Rasor in Sackcloth, pulling in Lady Fancyf. and Madamois.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: If they won't, here comes an Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Heavens, what have we here?

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: A Villain,— but a Repenting Villain. Stuff which Saints in all Ages have been made of.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Rasor.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What means this suddain Metamorphose?

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Nothing: without my Pardon.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: What Pardon do you want?

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Imprimis, Your Ladiships; For a Damnable Lye made upon your Spotless Virtue, and set to the Tune of Spring-Garden.
