[To Sir Iohn] Next, At my Generous Master's Feet I bend, for Interrupting his more Noble Thoughts with Phantomes of Disgraceful Cuckoldom.
[To Const.] Thirdly, I to this Gentleman apply, for making him the Hero of my Romance.
[To Heartf.] Fourthly, Your Pardon, Noble Sir, I ask, for Clandestinely Marrying you, without either bidding of Banns; Bishop's Licence, Friends Consent— or your own Knowledge.
[To Bel.] And lastly, to my good young Ladies Clemency I come, for pretending the Corn was sow'd in the Ground, before ever the Plough had been in the Field.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: [aside.] So that after all, 'tis a Moot Point, whether I am a Cuckold or not.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well Sir, upon Condition you confess all, I'll Pardon you my self, and try to obtain as much from the rest of the Company. But I must know then, who 'tis has put you upon all this Mischief?

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: Sathan, and his Equipage. Woman tempted me, Lust weaken'd me;— And so the Devil overcame me: As fell Adam, so fell I.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then pray, Mr. Adam, will you make us acquainted with your Eve.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: to Madam. Unmask, for the honour of France.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Madamoiselle?

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Me ask ten tousand Pardon of all de good Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: Why this Mystery thickens instead of clearing up.
[To Ras.] You Son of a Whore you, put us out of our pain.

sp.speaker: Ras.
sp.p: One moment brings Sun-shine.

Shewing Madamois. 'Tis true; This is the Woman, that tempted me. But this is the Serpent, that tempted the Woman; And if my Prayers might be heard, her Punishment for so doing, shou'd be like the Serpent's of Old.
Pulls off Lady F's Mask. She should lie upon her Face, all the days of her Life.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Lady Fancyfull.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Impertinent.

sp.speaker: Lady B.
sp.p: Ridiculous.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I hope your Ladiship will give me leave to wish you Joy, since you have own'd your Marriage your self.
Mr. Heartfree: I vow 'twas strangely wicked in you, to think of another Wife, when you had one already so Charming as her Ladiship.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady F.
sp.p: aside Confusion seize 'em as it seizes me.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: Que le Diable e toute ce Maraut de Rasor.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Ladiship seems disorder'd: A Breeding Qualm, perhaps. Mr. Heartfree: Your Bottle of Hungry Water to your Lady. Why Madam, he stands as Unconcern'd, as if he were your Husband in earnest

sp.speaker: Lady Fancy.
sp.p: Your Mirth's as nauseous as your self Bellinda.
You think you triumph o'er a Rival now.

Helas ma pauvre fill●. Where e'er I'm Rival, there's no cause for Mirth. No, my poor Wretch; 'tis from another Principle I have acted. I knew that thing there wou'd make so perverse a Husband, and you so impertinent a Wife; that left your mutual Plagues shou'd make you both run Mad, I charitably wou'd have broke the Match. He, he, he, he, he. Exit laughing affectedly. Madamoiselle following her.

sp.speaker: Madamois.
sp.p: He, he, he, he, he.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Iohn.
sp.p: [aside.] Why now this Woman will be married to somebody too.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Poor Creature, what a Passion she's in: But I forgive her.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Since you have so much goodness for her, I hope you'll Pardon my Offence too, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: There will be no great difficulty in that, since I am guilty of an equal Fault.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: Then Pardons being past on all Sides, Pray let's to Church to conclude the Day's Work.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: But before you go, let me treat you pray with a Song, a new married Lady made within this Week; it may be of use to you both.

lg.l: WHen yeilding first to Damon's flame
I sunk into his Arms,
He swore he'd ever be the same,
Then rifl'd all my Charms.
But fond of what h'ad long desir'd,
Too greedy of his Prey,
My Shepherds flame, alas, expir'd
Before the Virge of Day.
My Innocence in Lovers Wars,
Reproach'd his quick defeat.
Confus'd, Asham'd, and Bath'd in Tears,
I mourn'd his Cold Retreat.
At length, Ah Shepherdess, cry'd he,
Wou'd you my Fire renew,
Alas you must retreat like me,
I'm lost if you pursue.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: So Madam; Now had the Parson but done his Business—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You'd be half weary of your Bargain.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.p: No sure, I might dispense with one Night's Lodging.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'm ready to try, Sir.

sp.speaker: Heart.
sp.l: Then Let's to Church:
And if it be our Chance, to disagree,—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Take heed:— The surly Husband's Fate you see.
